paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO, Governor of Messina;HERO, his daughter; and BEATRICE his niece, with a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO, Governor of Messina;HERO, his daughter; and BEATRICE, his niece, enter with a MESSENGER

paragraphs.original:
I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Aragon comes this
night to Messina.
paragraphs.translated:
(holding a letter) According to this letter,
Don Pedro of Aragon and his army are coming to Messina tonight.
(holding a letter)
Don

paragraphs.original:
He is very near by this. He was not three leagues off when
I left him.
paragraphs.translated: He must be very near by now. When I left him, he was less than nine miles from here.

paragraphs.original: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
paragraphs.translated: How many noblemen were killed in the battle you just fought?

paragraphs.original: But few of any sort, and none of name.
paragraphs.translated: Not many, and no one important.

paragraphs.original:
A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full
numbers. I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much
honor on a young Florentine called Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: A victory in battle is twice as victorious when all the soldiers return home safely. This letter also says that Don Pedro has given honors to a young man from Florence named Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered by
Don Pedro. He hath borne himself beyond the promise of
his age, doing in the figure of a lamb the feats of a lion. He
hath indeed better bettered expectation than you must
expect of me to tell you how.
paragraphs.translated: Claudio deserves to be honored, and Don Pedro has rewarded him accordingly. Claudio has done more than anyone would expect of a man his age. He looks like a lamb but fights like a lion. He has so greatly exceeded all expectations that I can't even describe all he's done.

paragraphs.original:
He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of
it.
paragraphs.translated: He has an uncle here in Messina who will be glad to hear this news.

paragraphs.original:
I have already delivered him letters, and there appears
much joy in him - even so much that joy could not show
itself modest enough without a badge of bitterness.
paragraphs.translated: I have delivered some letters to his uncle, and he seemed very happy. He got so emotional that he actually looked like he was in pain.

paragraphs.original: Did he break out into tears?
paragraphs.translated: Did he start weeping?

paragraphs.original: In great measure.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, heavily.

paragraphs.original:
A kind overflow of kindness. There are no faces truer than
those that are so washed. How much better is it to weep at
joy than to joy at weeping!
paragraphs.translated: That's a very natural display of affection. There's no face more sincere than one washed in tears. And it's definitely better to cry because you're happy than laugh because you're sad!

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, is Signor Montanto returned from the wars or
no?
paragraphs.translated:
Please tell me, has Signior
Montanto returned from battle?
Montanto

paragraphs.original:
I know none of that name, lady. There was none such in the
army of any sort.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know anyone with that name, ma'am. There was no Signior Montanto in our army.

paragraphs.original: What is he that you ask for, niece?
paragraphs.translated: Who are you talking about, niece?

paragraphs.original: My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua.
paragraphs.translated: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

paragraphs.original: Oh, he's returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, yes, Benedick has returned and is as cheerful as ever.

paragraphs.original:
He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged Cupid at
the flight, and my uncle's Fool, reading the challenge,
subscribed for Cupid and challenged him at the bird-bolt.
I pray you, how many hath he killed and eaten in these
wars? But how many hath he killed? For indeed I promised
to eat all of his killing.
paragraphs.translated:
Benedick once put up a public notice in Messina challenging Cupid to an archery match. My uncle's jester accepted the contest on Cupid's behalf but used toy arrows at the shooting match. But tell me, how many men did he kill and eat in this battle? I promised him I would eat anyone he killed.
Benedick

paragraphs.original:
Faith, niece, you tax Signor Benedick too much, but he'll be
meet with you, I doubt it not.
paragraphs.translated: For God's sake, Beatrice, you're criticizing Signior Benedick too heavily. But I'm sure he'll get even with you.

paragraphs.original: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
paragraphs.translated: Signior Benedick served well in the war, my lady.

paragraphs.original:
You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it. He is a
very valiant trencherman. He hath an excellent stomach.
paragraphs.translated: You had rotten food, and he helped you eat it. He's a very brave eater - he has a strong stomach.

paragraphs.original: And a good soldier too, lady.
paragraphs.translated: He's a good soldier too, lady.

paragraphs.original: And a good soldier to a lady, but what is he to a lord?
paragraphs.translated: He's a good soldier to a lady? Well then, what is he to a lord?

paragraphs.original:
A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stuffed with all honorable
virtues.
paragraphs.translated: He's a lord to a lord and a man to a man. He is positively stuffed with honorable virtues.

paragraphs.original:
It is so indeed. He is no less than a stuffed man. But for the
stuffing - well, we are all mortal.
paragraphs.translated: Absolutely - he is stuffed, like a dummy. As for what he's stuffed with - well, nobody's perfect.

paragraphs.original:
You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of
merry war betwixt Signor Benedick and her. They never
meet but there's a skirmish of wit between them.
paragraphs.translated: Please don't take my niece the wrong way, sir. Benedick and Beatrice have been waging a war of wits between themselves. Whenever they meet, there's a little battle.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict four of his
five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man
governed with one, so that if he have wit enough to keep
himself warm, let him bear it for a difference between
himself and his horse, for it is all the wealth that he hath left
to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion
now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.
paragraphs.translated: And I always win. The last time we fought, he was so dazed by the end that he wasn't much smarter than his horse. So tell me, who is he hanging around with these days? Every month he has a new best friend.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated: Is that possible?

paragraphs.original:
Very easily possible. He wears his faith but as the fashion of
his hat; it ever changes with the next block.
paragraphs.translated: It's entirely possible. He's incredibly fickle - his affection changes faster than the latest fashions.

paragraphs.original: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.
paragraphs.translated: I can see you don't like this gentleman.

paragraphs.original:
No. An he were, I would burn my study. But I pray you,
who is his companion? Is there no young squarer now that
will make a voyage with him to the devil?
paragraphs.translated: No, absolutely not. But please tell me, who's his best friend? Isn't there some new swaggering young ruffian who will happily go to hell with Benedick?

paragraphs.original: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: He spends most of his time with the good, noble Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease! He is sooner
caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently
mad. God help the noble Claudio! If he have caught the
Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God, Benedick will plague him like a disease! Benedick is an infection that's easy to catch but hard to get rid of - and he'll drive you crazy once you've been infected. God help Claudio! If he's caught the Benedick, he'll lose all his money before he's cured.

paragraphs.original: I will hold friends with you, lady.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to make sure I stay on your good side, lady.

paragraphs.original: Do, good friend.
paragraphs.translated: Do that, my friend.

paragraphs.original: You will never run mad, niece.
paragraphs.translated: You will never fall victim to Benedick's charms, my niece.

paragraphs.original: No, not till a hot January.
paragraphs.translated: No, not until we see a hot January.

paragraphs.original: Don Pedro is approached.
paragraphs.translated: Don Pedro is here.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, Prince of Aragon, with CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,BALTHASAR, and DON JOHN the bastard
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO, Prince of Aragon, enters with CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,BALTHASAR, and
DON JOHN, the bastard.

paragraphs.original:
Good Signor Leonato, are you come to meet your trouble?
The fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter
it.
paragraphs.translated: My dear Signior Leonato, hosting my whole army is such a huge burden, but you accept it - and me - with open arms. Most people choose to avoid trouble, but you run to it.

paragraphs.original:
Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your
Grace, for trouble being gone, comfort should remain, but
when you depart from me, sorrow abides and happiness
takes his leave.
paragraphs.translated:
You are never trouble to this house, your Grace. It's comforting when trouble departs. But when you leave, you take happiness with you and leave sorrow in its place.
you

paragraphs.original:
You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is your
daughter.
Her mother hath many times told me so.
paragraphs.translated: That's what her mother always tells me.

paragraphs.original: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?
paragraphs.translated: Did you doubt that she was your daughter, since you had to ask her mother?

paragraphs.original: Signor Benedick, no, for then were you a child.
paragraphs.translated:
(teasing) Of course not, Signior Benedick. You were only a child when my daughter was born, and not yet old enough to seduce my wife.
(teasing)

paragraphs.original:
You have it full, Benedick. We may guess by this what you
are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers herself. - Be
happy, lady, for you are like an honorable father.
paragraphs.translated: Ah, he got you back, Benedick! Leonato clearly knows your reputation with women. Seriously, though, the lady resembles Leonato so much that there can be no doubt about who her father is. Congratulations, lady: you resemble a most honorable man.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO and DON PEDRO move to one side, still talking
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and DON PEDRO move to one side, still talking.

paragraphs.original:
If Signor Leonato be her father, she would not have his
head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.
paragraphs.translated: Well, even if he is her father, I'm sure she wouldn't want to have the head of the old man on her shoulders!

paragraphs.original:
I wonder that you will still be talking, Signor Benedick.
Nobody marks you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm amazed you're still talking, Signior Benedick. No one's listening to you.

paragraphs.original: What, my dear Lady Disdain! Are you yet living?
paragraphs.translated: Look, it's my dear Lady Disdain! Aren't you dead yet?

paragraphs.original:
Is it possible disdain should die while she hath such meet
food to feed it as Signor Benedick? Courtesy itself must
convert to disdain if you come in her presence.
paragraphs.translated: How could disdain die when you're here? When you're around, even Lady Courtesy becomes Lady Disdain.

paragraphs.original:
Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of
all ladies, only you excepted. And I would I could find in
my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love none.
paragraphs.translated: That makes Lady Courtesy a traitor. All ladies love me, except you. It's too bad I'm so hard-hearted, because I really don't love anyone.

paragraphs.original:
A dear happiness to women. They would else have been
troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold
blood I am of your humor for that. I had rather hear my dog
bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.
paragraphs.translated: Women are lucky, then. You would make a nasty suitor. Thankfully, I feel the same way you do. I have no need for romance. I would rather listen to my dog bark at a crow than hear a man swear that he loves me.

paragraphs.original:
God keep your Ladyship still in that mind, so some gentle-
man or other shall 'scape a predestinate scratched face.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I hope you stay in that frame of mind or some poor man will end up with his face all scratched up.

paragraphs.original:
Scratching could not make it worse an 'twere such a face as
yours were.
paragraphs.translated: If he has a face like yours, a good scratching couldn't make him look any worse.

paragraphs.original: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.
paragraphs.translated: Listen to you, instructing me like a parrot would.

paragraphs.original: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.
paragraphs.translated: I'd rather be a squawking bird than an animal like you.

paragraphs.original:
I would my horse had the speed of your tongue and so good
a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's name. I have done.
paragraphs.translated: I wish my horse moved as fast as your mouth and was as tireless. That's it - I'm done.

paragraphs.original: You always end with a jade's trick. I know you of old.
paragraphs.translated: You always slip out of the argument like this. I know you from before.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO and DON PEDRO come forward
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and DON PEDRO come forward

paragraphs.original:
That is the sum of all, Leonato. - Signior Claudio and
Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you
all. I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month, and he
heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer. I dare
swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart.
paragraphs.translated: And that's everything, Leonato. - Claudio, Benedick - my dear friend Leonato has invited you all to stay here at Messina. I told him we'll stay for at least a month, and he says that he hopes we'll stay longer. I think he's actually serious, and not just being polite.

paragraphs.original:
If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn. (to DON
(to
JOHN) Let me bid you welcome, my lord. Being reconciled
)
to the Prince your brother, I owe you all duty.
I thank you. I am not of many words, but I thank you.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you. I'm not a man who talks a lot, but I thank you.

paragraphs.original: Please it your Grace lead on?
paragraphs.translated: If it pleases you, your highness, will you lead us all inside?

paragraphs.original: Your hand, Leonato. We will go together.
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand, Leonato. We will go in together.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt. Manent BENEDICK andCLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except BENEDICK andCLAUDIO.

paragraphs.original: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?
paragraphs.translated: Benedick, did you notice Signior Leonato's daughter?

paragraphs.original: I noted her not, but I looked on her.
paragraphs.translated: I saw her, but I didn't notice her.

paragraphs.original: Is she not a modest young lady?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't she a well-mannered young lady?

paragraphs.original:
Do you question me as an honest man should do, for my
simple true judgment? Or would you have me speak after
my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?
paragraphs.translated: Do you want my true opinion? Or do you want me to criticize her like I do all women?

paragraphs.original: No, I pray thee speak in sober judgment.
paragraphs.translated: No, please, speak seriously.

paragraphs.original:
Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high praise, too
brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise. Only
this commendation I can afford her, that were she other
than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but
as she is, I do not like her.
paragraphs.translated: Well, it seems to me that she is too short to be praised highly, too dark to be praised fairly, and too small to be praised greatly. I can only say this about her: if she looked different than she does, she would be ugly, and since she can't be anything but herself, I don't like her.

paragraphs.original:
Thou thinkest I am in sport. I pray thee tell me truly how
thou lik'st her.
paragraphs.translated: You think I'm kidding. Please tell me seriously what you think of her.

paragraphs.original: Would you buy her, that you enquire after her?
paragraphs.translated: Are you thinking of buying her? Is that why you're asking?

paragraphs.original: Can the world buy such a jewel?
paragraphs.translated: Would it even be possible to buy a jewel as rare and precious as Hero?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad
brow? Or do you play the flouting jack, to tell us Cupid is
a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in
what key shall a man take you to go in the song?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and you could buy a case to put it in, too. But tell me, are you speaking seriously? Or are you just teasing? If I'm going to sing along with you, I need to know what key you're singing in.

paragraphs.original: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.
paragraphs.translated: I think she's the most wonderful woman I've ever laid eyes on.

paragraphs.original:
I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such matter.
There's her cousin, an she were not possessed with a fury,
exceeds her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the
last of December. But I hope you have no intent to turn
husband, have you?
paragraphs.translated: I'm still young enough to see without glasses, and I don't see what you're talking about. If her cousin Beatrice didn't have such a nasty temper, she'd be so much more beautiful than Hero that it would be like comparing May to December. But, hey, this doesn't mean you're looking to get married, does it?

paragraphs.original:
I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the
contrary, if Hero would be my wife.
paragraphs.translated: Even if I had sworn never to marry, I wouldn't trust myself to keep that promise if Hero would marry me.

paragraphs.original:
Is 't come to this? In faith, hath not the world one man but
he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a
bachelor of three-score again? Go to, i' faith, an thou wilt
needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it, and
sigh away Sundays. Look, Don Pedro is returned to seek
you.
paragraphs.translated: What's going on these days? Isn't there one man left in the world who knows not to take a wife? She's just going to cheat on him. Will I never see a sixty-year old bachelor again or will all men be swindled into marriage while they're young? Go ahead, then, if you have to yoke yourself to marriage, like an ox carrying his load, and throw away your free time. Look, Don Pedro has come back for you.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO enters.

paragraphs.original:
What secret hath held you here that you followed not to
Leonato's?
paragraphs.translated: What secrets between you have kept you from following us to Leonato's?

paragraphs.original: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.
paragraphs.translated: Your highness will have to force me to tell.

paragraphs.original: I charge thee on thy allegiance.
paragraphs.translated: Your loyalty to me requires you to tell me what you've been talking about.

paragraphs.original:
You hear, Count Claudio? I can be secret as a dumb man, I
would have you think so, but on my allegiance - mark you
this, on my allegiance - (to DON PEDRO) he is in love. With
(to
)
who? Now, that is your Grace's part. Mark how short his
answer is: with Hero, Leonato's short daughter.
paragraphs.translated:
Look, Claudio, I can keep secrets like a mute; I want you to know that. But I owe Don Pedro my allegiance - look, I have to tell him - (to DON PEDRO) Claudio is in love. With whom? That's what you're supposed to ask me next, your Grace. Look how short the answer is - with Hero, Leonato's short daughter.
have
(to
)

paragraphs.original: If this were so, so were it uttered.
paragraphs.translated: If you say so.

paragraphs.original:
Like the old tale, my lord: "It is not so nor 'twas not so but,
indeed, God forbid it should be so."
paragraphs.translated: Listen to him deny it, like that man in the old tale "Mr. Fox": "It isn't true and wasn't true and God forbid it should be so."

paragraphs.original:
If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be
otherwise.
paragraphs.translated: Unless my feelings change very soon, I have to admit it's true.

paragraphs.original: Amen, if you love her, for the lady is very well worthy.
paragraphs.translated: It's good if you love Hero, because she's worthy of your love.

paragraphs.original: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: You're trying to trick me, my lord.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, I speak my thought.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, I'm telling you what I honestly think.

paragraphs.original: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.
paragraphs.translated: And I swear I spoke honestly to Benedick - I am in love with Hero.

paragraphs.original: And by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.
paragraphs.translated: And I swear all up and down I spoke honestly when I said that this was a horrible idea.

paragraphs.original: That I love her, I feel.
paragraphs.translated: I feel that I love her.

paragraphs.original: That she is worthy, I know.
paragraphs.translated: I know that she is worthy of that love.

paragraphs.original:
That I neither feel how she should be loved nor know how
she should be worthy is the opinion that fire cannot melt
out
of me. I will die in it at the stake.
paragraphs.translated:
I, on the other hand, don't feel how she could be loved and don't know how she could be worthy. Even fire can't melt that opinion out of me. You could burn me at the stake, and I'd still think this.
feel
know

paragraphs.original: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty.
paragraphs.translated: You never did believe in the power of beauty.

paragraphs.original: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.
paragraphs.translated: Or in the power of reason.

paragraphs.original:
That a woman conceived me, I thank her. That she brought
me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks. But that I
will have a recheat winded in my forehead or hang my bugle
in an invisible baldrick, all women shall pardon me.
Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will
do myself the right to trust none. And the fine is, for the
which I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.
paragraphs.translated: I was conceived by a woman, and I thank her very much for all her effort. And then she brought me up, and I thank her for that, too. But all the other women will have to forgive me for not being willing to be made a fool of - cheated on by a wife. I don't want to insult any particular woman by doubting and mistrusting her, so I'll just avoid them all. And the conclusion of this is that I'll live as a bachelor - and, with the money I save, dress better.

paragraphs.original: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, before I die I'm going to see you sick with love.

paragraphs.original:
With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not
with love. Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than
I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a
ballad-maker's pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel
house for the sign of blind Cupid.
paragraphs.translated: With anger, with fever, or with hunger, sure, my friend, but never sick with love. If you can prove that I'll ever be so in love that I can't be brought to my senses with a good round of beers, you can pluck out my eyes with a love-poet's pen and hang me on a brothel's door where the picture of blind Cupid usually goes.

paragraphs.original:
Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove
a notable argument.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be sure to remember this fuss you've made, in case you ever do fall in love. That'll be news.

paragraphs.original:
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me, and he
that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder and called
Adam.
paragraphs.translated: If I ever change my mind, you can use me for target practice. And whoever hits the bull's eye gets to be a hero.

paragraphs.original:
Well, as time shall try.
In time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.
paragraphs.translated: Well, time will tell. Even the most savage bull is eventually domesticated.

paragraphs.original:
The savage bull may, but if ever the sensible Benedick bear
it, pluck off the bull's horns and set them in my forehead,
and let me be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they
write "Here is good horse to hire" let them signify under my
sign "Here you may see Benedick the married man."
paragraphs.translated: Maybe the bull is, but if I am ever domesticated, you can take that bull's horns and put them right on my forehead, as my wife is sure to cuckold me soon enough. You might as well hang a big sign with enormous lettering around my neck. But instead of it saying "Horse for hire," it will say "Take a look at Benedick, the married man."

paragraphs.original: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.
paragraphs.translated: If that ever happened, you'd go absolutely mad.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thou
wilt quake for this shortly.
paragraphs.translated: Well, if Cupid hasn't used up all his arrows in Venice, where the courtesans are famous for making men lovesick, he'll get you to quiver and shake. Just you wait.

paragraphs.original: I look for an earthquake too, then.
paragraphs.translated: That's about as likely as an earthquake.

paragraphs.original:
Well, you temporize with the hours. In the meantime, good
Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato's. Commend me to
him and tell him I will not fail him at supper, for indeed he
hath made great preparation.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you'll soften as time passes. While you're waiting for that to happen, though, hurry to Leonato's. Give him my respects, and tell him I'll definitely be there for dinner, since I know he has gone to great lengths for this meal.

paragraphs.original:
I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage,
and so I commit you -
paragraphs.translated: I think I can handle this mission. And so I commit you -

paragraphs.original: To the tuition of God. From my house, if I had it -
paragraphs.translated: "Into God's hands. From my house, if I had a house - "

paragraphs.original: The sixth of July. Your loving friend, Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: "The sixth of July. Sincerely, your loving friend, Benedick."

paragraphs.original:
Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is
sometimes guarded with fragments and the guards are but
slightly basted on neither. Ere you flout old ends any
further, examine your conscience. And so I leave you.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, stop joking around. You know, sometimes you two dress up your conversation with flimsy little bits of wit that don't hold together too well. Before you make
fun of everyone else, look at yourselves in the mirror! And with that, I'm leaving.
fun

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: My liege, your highness now may do me good.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, you could really help me out now.

paragraphs.original:
My love is thine to teach. Teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
paragraphs.translated: I am at your service. Just tell me what you want me to do, and however hard it is, you'll see that I'm eager to do it.

paragraphs.original: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Does Leonato have a son, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
No child but Hero; she's his only heir.
Dost thou affect her, Claudio?
paragraphs.translated: Hero is his only child, and his only heir. Do you like her, Claudio?

paragraphs.original:
O, my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I looked upon her with a soldier's eye,
That liked but had a rougher task in hand
Than to drive liking to the name of love.
But now I am returned and that war thoughts
Have left their places vacant, in their rooms
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying I liked her ere I went to wars.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, my lord, when we left Messina to fight the war, I looked at Hero with the eyes of a soldier. I liked what I saw, but my mind was so occupied with the rough, violent task ahead of me that there was no chance that like would turn intolove. But now that I'm back, the room in my head that I used to fill with war plans has become crowded with soft and delicate feelings. They all lead me to the same thought - how beautiful young Hero is and how I must have liked her even before I left to fight.
like
love

paragraphs.original:
Thou wilt be like a lover presently
And tire the hearer with a book of words.
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,
And thou shalt have her. Was 't not to this end
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?
paragraphs.translated: You will become a true lover soon, and exhaust your friends with your endless chatter about your feelings. Look, if you really love the beautiful Hero, enjoy it. I will speak to her and her father about the matter, and I'll convince Leonato to promise Hero to you. Isn't that the reason you told me all this?

paragraphs.original:
How sweetly you do minister to love,
That know love's grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.
paragraphs.translated: You can see that I'm sick with love, and you're taking care of me in just the right way! But I didn't want you to think that I'm hasty in my emotions. I was going to explain my feelings with a longer story.

paragraphs.original:
What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity.
Look what will serve is fit. 'Tis once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy.
I know we shall have reveling tonight.
I will assume thy part in some disguise
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale.
Then after to her father will I break,
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.
In practice let us put it presently.
paragraphs.translated: Why speak longer than you have to? That's like building a bridge wider than the river it crosses. Whatever gets the job done is best. You love Hero; that's all I need to know to want to find a remedy. They're going to have a costume party with dancing tonight. I'll disguise myself as you and pour out "my" feelings to Hero, taking her prisoner with the force of my love story. Then I'll talk to her father. And in the end, she's yours! Let's get started right away.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO andANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO enter.

paragraphs.original:
How now, brother, where is my cousin, your son? Hath he
provided this music?
paragraphs.translated: Hey, brother. Tell me, where is my nephew, your son? Has he taken care of the music?

paragraphs.original:
He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell you strange
news that you yet dreamt not of.
paragraphs.translated: He is taking care of it as we speak. But brother, I have some strange news for you.

paragraphs.original: Are they good?
paragraphs.translated: Is it good news?

paragraphs.original:
As the events stamps them, but they have a good cover;
they show well outward. The Prince and Count Claudio,
walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine orchard, were
thus much overheard by a man of mine: the Prince
discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter
and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance, and if he
found her accordant, he meant to take the present time by
the top and instantly break with you of it.
paragraphs.translated: Well, it seems like good news. A servant of mine overheard the Prince and Claudio talking as they walked through my orchard. The Prince said that he is in love with Hero, your daughter, and that he is going to tell her so at the dance tonight. If he she wants to marry him, too, he's going to find you and ask for her hand immediately.

paragraphs.original: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
paragraphs.translated: Is this servant of yours a smart man?

paragraphs.original:
A good sharp fellow. I will send for him, and question him
yourself.
paragraphs.translated: He's very bright. I'll get him to come here, and you can ask him yourself.

paragraphs.original:
No, no, we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself. But I
will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the
better prepared for an answer if peradventure this be true.
Go you and tell her of it.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, until it comes true we'll pretend it was just a dream we had. But my daughter should know about this, so she can be prepared with an answer just in case. Go to her and tell her for me.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO 's son, with a musician and attendants
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO 's son enters with a musician and attendants.

paragraphs.original:
Cousins, you know what you have to do. - O, I cry you
mercy, friend. Go you with me and I will use your skill. - 
Good cousin, have a care this busy time.
paragraphs.translated: Cousins, you all have work to do. - Oh, I beg your pardon. Come with me now, and help me out.  - Dear cousin, please be careful during this busy time.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON JOHN andCONRAD
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN and CONRAD enter.

paragraphs.original:
What the goodyear, my lord, why are you thus out of
measure sad?
paragraphs.translated: Really, my lord, why are you so excessively sad?

paragraphs.original:
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds. Therefore
the sadness is without limit.
paragraphs.translated: The things that cause my sadness are without limit. Therefore my sadness is without limit.

paragraphs.original: You should hear reason.
paragraphs.translated: You should listen to reason. Then you'd stop being so gloomy.

paragraphs.original: And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?
paragraphs.translated: And after I have sat and listened to reason, what's my prize?

paragraphs.original: If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.
paragraphs.translated: If not an end to your suffering, then at least you'll have the means to endure it patiently.

paragraphs.original:
I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayst thou art, born
under Saturn, goest about to apply a moral medicine to a
mortifying mischief. I cannot hide what I am. I must be sad
when I have cause and smile at no man's jests, eat when I
have stomach and wait for no man's leisure, sleep when I am
drowsy and tend on no man's business, laugh when I am
merry and claw no man in his humor.
paragraphs.translated: I'm amazed that you - being such a moody man yourself - are moralizing about my deadly condition. I can't hide what I am. I'll be sad when I have reason to be sad and won't smile at anybody's jokes. I'll eat when I'm hungry and won't wait until it's convenient. I'll sleep when I'm tired and won't rouse myself for anything. I'll laugh when I'm happy and won't flatter and fawn over anyone.

paragraphs.original:
Yea, but you must not make the full show of this till you
may do it without controlment. You have of late stood out
against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his
grace, where it is impossible you should take true root but
by the fair weather that you make yourself. It is needful that
you frame the season for your own harvest.
paragraphs.translated: Sure, but don't do it at full volume until there's no danger in it. Not long ago you challenged and opposed your brother, and it is only very recently that he has forgiven you. You need to act carefully if you're going to stay in his good graces. You have to wait for the appropriate time to let loose.

paragraphs.original:
I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace,
and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to
fashion a carriage to rob love from any. In this, though I
cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be
denied but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with a
muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I have
decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my mouth, I would
bite; if I had my liberty, I would do my liking. In the
meantime, let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.
paragraphs.translated: I'd rather be a weed in a hedge than a rose in my brother's garden. It suits me more to be hated by everyone than to put on a fancy show and trick people into loving me. Though I am not a flattering, righteous man, at least you can say that I am honest about being a villain. My brother trusts me now? Yeah - as much as a master trusts the dog he muzzles or the peasant he "frees" by chaining a big block around the man's foot. If my mouth were unrestrained, I'd bite. If I were free, I'd do what I pleased. Until that happens, let me be who I am and don't try to change me.

paragraphs.original: Can you make no use of your discontent?
paragraphs.translated: Can't you somehow use your dissatisfaction to your own advantage?

paragraphs.original: I make all use of it, for I use it only. Who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: I use it all the time, since it's all that I have. Who's that?

paragraphs.original: Enter BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO enters.

paragraphs.original: What news, Borachio?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on, Borachio?

paragraphs.original:
I came yonder from a great supper. The Prince your
brother
is royally entertained by Leonato, and I can give you
intelligence of an intended marriage.
paragraphs.translated: I just came from a great feast where Leonato is entertaining the Prince, your brother. I can give you information about an intended marriage.

paragraphs.original:
Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? What is he
for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?
paragraphs.translated: Will this give me an opportunity to make some mischief? Who is this fool who wants all the fuss of marriage?

paragraphs.original: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.
paragraphs.translated: Your brother's right-hand man.

paragraphs.original: Who? The most exquisite Claudio?
paragraphs.translated: Who? That pretty boy, Claudio?

paragraphs.original: Even he.
paragraphs.translated: That's the one.

paragraphs.original: A proper squire. And who, and who? Which way looks he?
paragraphs.translated: He's a very fancy gentleman. And who's the girl who has caught his eye?

paragraphs.original: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
paragraphs.translated: Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

paragraphs.original: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?
paragraphs.translated: A lively young one! How did you learn about this?

paragraphs.original:
Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty
room, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in
sad conference. I whipped me behind the arras, and there
heard it agreed upon that the Prince should woo Hero for
himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count
Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: I was hired to perfume all the rooms in Leonato's house. As I was working on one musty room, the Prince and Claudio entered. They were in the middle of a serious conversation. I quickly hid behind a tapestry and heard them agree that the Prince would court Hero tonight at the dance and, once he won her consent to marry, would give her to Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
Come, come, let us thither. This may prove food to my
displeasure. That young start-up hath all the glory of my
overthrow. If I can cross him any way, I bless myself every
way. You are both sure, and will assist me?
paragraphs.translated: Come, let's go to the dance. This just may cheer me up. Claudio, the young upstart, was responsible for keeping me from gaining power over my brother. If there's any way I can spoil his life, I'll be overjoyed. You'll both help me, right?

paragraphs.original: To the death, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Until the day we die, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
Let us to the great supper. Their cheer is the greater that I
am subdued. Would the cook were o' my mind! Shall we go
prove what's to be done?
paragraphs.translated: Let's go to this great feast. They'll be even happier now that my mood has lightened. It's too bad the cook doesn't think like me; she would have poisoned them all if she did. Should we go check out the scene?

paragraphs.original: We'll wait upon your lordship.
paragraphs.translated: Lead the way, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO,ANTONIO, HERO,BEATRICE, URSULA andMARGARET
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO, ANTONIO HERO BEATRICE URSULA, and MARGARET enter.

paragraphs.original: Was not Count John here at supper?
paragraphs.translated: Wasn't Don John at dinner tonight?

paragraphs.original: I saw him not.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't see him.

paragraphs.original:
How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him but I
am heartburned an hour after.
paragraphs.translated: That man always looks so sour! Just looking at him gives me heartburn.

paragraphs.original: He is of a very melancholy disposition.
paragraphs.translated: He has a very gloomy attitude.

paragraphs.original:
He were an excellent man that were made just in the
midway between him and Benedick. The one is too like an
image and says nothing, and the other too like my lady's
eldest son, evermore tattling.
paragraphs.translated: It would be excellent if they could make a man halfway between Don John and Benedick. One of them is too much like a painting of a man - he never speaks - and the other is too much like a spoiled little boy, always chattering.

paragraphs.original:
Then half Signor Benedick's tongue in Count John's
mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signor
Benedick's face -
paragraphs.translated: So, the man would talk half as much as Benedick and be half as serious as Don John -

paragraphs.original:
With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough
in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the
world, if he could get her goodwill.
paragraphs.translated: And if he were handsome, agile, and rich, too, he could have any woman in the world - all he'd need was her good will.

paragraphs.original:
By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband if
thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.
paragraphs.translated: Really, niece, you'll never get a husband if you keep saying such harsh things about people.

paragraphs.original: In faith, she's too curst.
paragraphs.translated: Honestly, she is too ill-tempered.

paragraphs.original:
Too curst is more than curst. I shall lessen God's sending
that way, for it is said, "God sends a curst cow short horns,"
but to a cow too curst, he sends none.
paragraphs.translated:
Being "too ill-tempered" is different from being simply "ill-tempered," right? So I suppose that means I can escape God's punishment, for in the old proverb, it is said that "God gives an ill-tempered cow short horns" so that she can't inflict damage on anyone. But it doesn't say anything about a cow that is too ill-tempered.
too

paragraphs.original: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.
paragraphs.translated: So then, for being too argumentative, God won't send you any horns?

paragraphs.original:
Just, if he send me no husband, for the which blessing I am
at him upon my knees every morning and evening. Lord, I
could not endure a husband with a beard on his face! I had
rather lie in the woolen.
paragraphs.translated:
Exactly. I pray every morning and night that the Lord won't send me a husband. Really, I couldn't stand a husband with a beard. I'd rather be wrapped in scratchy blankets all night.
Exactly

paragraphs.original: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
paragraphs.translated: Maybe you will find a husband without a beard.

paragraphs.original:
What should I do with him? Dress him in my apparel and
make him my waiting gentlewoman? He that hath a beard
is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than
a man; and he that is more than a youth is not for me, and
he that is less than a man, I am not for him. Therefore I will
even take sixpence in earnest of the bearherd, and lead his
apes into hell.
paragraphs.translated: And then what would I do with him? Dress him up in my clothes and pretend he's my lady servant? If he has a beard, he's more than a boy; if he doesn't have a beard, he's less than a man. If he's more than a boy, he's not the one for me, and if he's less than a man, I'm not the one for him. They say that women who die unmarried are destined to lead the apes to hell, and I suppose that'll be my fate as well.

paragraphs.original: Well then, go you into hell?
paragraphs.translated: So you'll go to hell?

paragraphs.original:
No, but to the gate, and there will the devil meet me like an
old cuckold with horns on his head, and say, "Get you to
heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here's no place for you
maids." So deliver I up my apes and away to Saint Peter. For
the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there
live we as merry as the day is long.
paragraphs.translated: No, just to the gates of hell, where the devil will meet me, with the horns on his head like a cuckold, and say, "Go up to heaven, Beatrice. Hell is no place for you virgins." So I'll fly up to heaven (leaving the apes behind) where I'll be met by Saint Peter guarding heaven's gates. He will show me the part of heaven where the bachelors sit, and I'll have fun there forever.

paragraphs.original:
(to HERO)Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled by your
(to
)
father.

Yes, faith, it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy and say,
"Father, as it please you." But yet for all that, cousin, let
him be a handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy and
say, "Father, as it please me."
paragraphs.translated: Surely, my cousin has a duty to please her father. But if the husband her father chooses isn't handsome, she should sweetly tell her father that she will please herself - with another one.

paragraphs.original: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.
paragraphs.translated: Well, niece, I hope that I will see you married one day.

paragraphs.original:
Not till God make men of some other metal than earth.
Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a
piece of valiant dust? To make an account of her life to a clod
of wayward marl? No, uncle, I'll none. Adam's sons are my
brethren, and truly I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.
paragraphs.translated:
No, I won't take a husband until they make men out of something other than dirt. What woman wouldn't be distressed, being lorded over by a handful of dust? Can you imagine being hitched to a lump of clay? No, uncle, I won't be married. And anyhow, if
Adam is the father of all mankind, then his sons are my brothers, and really I believe that incest is a sin.
Adam

paragraphs.original:
(to HERO) Daughter, remember what I told you. If the
(to
)
Prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be not wooed
in good time. If the Prince be too important, tell him there
is measure in everything, and so dance out the answer. For
hear me, Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a
Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace. The first suit is hot
and hasty like a Scotch jig, and full as fantastical; the
wedding, mannerly modest as a measure, full of state and
ancientry; and then comes repentance, and with his bad
legs falls into the cinquepace faster and faster till he sink
into his grave.
paragraphs.translated:
But cousin, make sure he woos you properly and appropriately. If he is too insistent, tell him that romance is like a dance: it has its own rhythm and timing. Look, the three stages of romance are like three different dances. The wooing is like a Scottish jig: hot and fast and full of whimsy and illusion. The wedding is a like a dance you would do before the King: proper and decorous. Finally, you get to the part where you regret having gotten married in the first place. It is like the lively
cinquepace: it goes faster and faster until you eventually topple over and die.
cinquepace

paragraphs.original: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.
paragraphs.translated: Niece, you are exceptionally perceptive.

paragraphs.original: I have a good eye, uncle. I can see a church by daylight.
paragraphs.translated: I have a good eye, uncle. I can see what's in broad daylight.

paragraphs.original: The revelers are entering, brother. Make good room.
paragraphs.translated: The partygoers have arrived. Let's give them room.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,BALTHASAR, DON JOHN,BORACHIO, MARGARET,URSULA and others, masked
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO,BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO,MARGARET, URSULA enter along with other partygoers. They're all wearing masks.

paragraphs.original: Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
paragraphs.translated: My lady, will you have a dance with me?

paragraphs.original: They begin to dance
paragraphs.translated: They begin to dance.

paragraphs.original:
So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, I am
yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.
paragraphs.translated: As long as you move gracefully, look handsome, and say nothing, I'm yours for the dance. And I'll even linger after I've gone.

paragraphs.original: With me in your company?
paragraphs.translated: Will I be with you then?

paragraphs.original: I may say so when I please.
paragraphs.translated: Perhaps, if I decide to let you.

paragraphs.original: And when please you to say so?
paragraphs.translated: And when will that be?

paragraphs.original:
When I like your favor, for God defend the lute should be
like the case!
paragraphs.translated: When I like the way you look, for God forbid your face be as ugly as your mask!

paragraphs.original: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.
paragraphs.translated:
My mask is like the roof of the poor
Philemon's humble cottage; underneath the mask, I am as magnificent as the glorious god Jove.
Philemon's

paragraphs.original: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, since Philemon's roof was thatched with straw, your mask should have a beard.

paragraphs.original: Speak low if you speak love.
paragraphs.translated: If you wish to speak of love, speak more softly.

paragraphs.original: They move aside. BALTHASAR andMARGARET move forward
paragraphs.translated: They move aside. BALTHASAR andMARGARET move forward.

paragraphs.original: Well, I would you did like me.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I wish you liked me.

paragraphs.original: So would not I for your own sake, for I have many ill qualities.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad I don't, for your sake. I have many awful qualities.

paragraphs.original: Which is one?
paragraphs.translated: Tell me one.

paragraphs.original: I say my prayers aloud.
paragraphs.translated: I say my prayers out loud.

paragraphs.original: I love you the better; the hearers may cry "Amen."
paragraphs.translated: That makes me love you even more. Everyone who hears you can shout, "Amen."

paragraphs.original: God match me with a good dancer!
paragraphs.translated: God give me a good dance partner!

paragraphs.original: Amen.
paragraphs.translated: Amen. That would be me.

paragraphs.original:
And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done!
Answer, clerk.
paragraphs.translated: And God take him away from me when we're finished dancing! Go ahead - say "Amen."

paragraphs.original: No more words. The clerk is answered.
paragraphs.translated: No more talking. I've got my answer.

paragraphs.original: They move aside. URSULA andANTONIO move forward.
paragraphs.translated: They move aside. URSULA andANTONIO move forward.

paragraphs.original: I know you well enough. You are Signor Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: I know who you are; you are Signior Antonio.

paragraphs.original: At a word, I am not.
paragraphs.translated: No, really, I'm not.

paragraphs.original: I know you by the waggling of your head.
paragraphs.translated: I can tell by the way you waggle your head.

paragraphs.original: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.
paragraphs.translated: Really, I'm only pretending to be him.

paragraphs.original:
You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very
man. Here's his dry hand up and down. You are he, you are
he.
paragraphs.translated: You could only imitate his imperfections so well if you were the man himself. Look, you've got his wrinkled hands. You are Antonio, you are he.

paragraphs.original: At a word, I am not.
paragraphs.translated: In short, I'm not.

paragraphs.original:
Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your
excellent wit? Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum, you are
he. Graces will appear, and there's an end.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, do you think I can't recognize you by your excellent wit? Can a good thing hide itself? Be quiet, you are Antonio. A man's virtues will always show themselves, and that's the end of that.

paragraphs.original: They move aside. BENEDICK andBEATRICE move forward.
paragraphs.translated: They move aside. BENEDICK andBEATRICE move forward.

paragraphs.original: Will you not tell me who told you so?
paragraphs.translated: Won't you tell me who told you that?

paragraphs.original: No, you shall pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: No, you'll have to excuse me.

paragraphs.original: Nor will you not tell me who you are?
paragraphs.translated: And you won't tell me who you are?

paragraphs.original: Not now.
paragraphs.translated: Not now.

paragraphs.original:
That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The
Hundred Merry Tales! Well this was Signor Benedick that
said so.
paragraphs.translated: Who said that I was disdainful, and that I got all my best lines out of a bad joke book?! Well, it must have been Signior Benedick.

paragraphs.original: What's he?
paragraphs.translated: Who's that?

paragraphs.original: I am sure you know him well enough.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sure you know him.

paragraphs.original: Not I, believe me.
paragraphs.translated: No I don't, believe me.

paragraphs.original: Did he never make you laugh?
paragraphs.translated: What, he never made you laugh?

paragraphs.original: I pray you, what is he?
paragraphs.translated: Please tell me, who is this man?

paragraphs.original:
Why, he is the Prince's jester, a very dull fool, only his gift
is in devising impossible slanders. None but libertines
delight in him, and the commendation is not in his wit but
in his villainy, for he both pleases men and angers them,
and then they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in
the fleet. I would he had boarded me.
paragraphs.translated: Why, he's the Prince's fool, and a very dull fool at that. His only talent is his capacity to come up with unbelievable slanders. Only the most immoral people enjoy his company, and they like him not for his wit but his outrageousness. He manages to both please and anger people; they laugh at him and then beat him up. I'm sure he's out there dancing. I could have sworn he trampled on me.

paragraphs.original: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.
paragraphs.translated: When I meet this gentleman, I'll tell him what you've said.

paragraphs.original:
Do, do. He'll but break a comparison or two on me, which,
peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into
melancholy, and then there's a partridge wing saved, for the
fool will eat no supper that night.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, please do. He'll say a few nasty things about me, and if nobody listens to him or laughs, he'll be thrown into a funk. And that will save a partridge wing from being eaten, because he'll be too miserable for dinner.

paragraphs.original: Music for the dance
paragraphs.translated: Music for the dance begins.

paragraphs.original: We must follow the leaders.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, we have to follow the leaders of the dance.

paragraphs.original: In every good thing.
paragraphs.translated: In every good thing they do.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next
turning.
paragraphs.translated: No, if they try to lead us to harm, I will leave the dance floor at the next song.

paragraphs.original: Dance, then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: There is a dance. Everyone exits except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, andCLAUDIO.

paragraphs.original:
(to BORACHIO) Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and
(to
)
hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The
ladies follow her, and but one visor remains.
And that is Claudio. I know him by his bearing.
paragraphs.translated: That's Claudio. I can tell by the way he carries himself.

paragraphs.original: You know me well. I am he.
paragraphs.translated: You know me too well. I am Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
Signor, you are very near my brother in his love. He is
enamored on Hero. I pray you, dissuade him from her. She
is no equal for his birth. You may do the part of an honest
man in it.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, my brother is very fond of you. He is in love with Hero. Please make him change his mind. She doesn't have the proper rank to marry the Prince. You would be doing a good service.

paragraphs.original: How know you he loves her?
paragraphs.translated: How do you know he loves her?

paragraphs.original: I heard him swear his affection.
paragraphs.translated: I heard him swear he did.

paragraphs.original: So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.
paragraphs.translated: I did too, and he also swore he would marry her tonight.

paragraphs.original: Come, let us to the banquet.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, let's get to the banquet.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DON JOHN andBORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN andBORACHIO exit.

paragraphs.original:
(unmasking)
(unmasking)
Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
'Tis certain so, the Prince woos for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love.
Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
Let every eye nogetiate for itself
And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
(taking off his mask)
(taking off his mask)
Though I said my name was Benedick, I heard this news with Claudio's ears. Of course the Prince wants Hero for himself. Friendship is enduring except when love is involved. Therefore, all lovers should speak for themselves. They should look for themselves, without asking someone else to get involved in their affairs. Beauty is a witch whose spells can turn loyalty into passion. This happens a lot, but it didn't occur to me that it would happen to me. Goodbye then, Hero.

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK enters.

paragraphs.original: Count Claudio?
paragraphs.translated: Claudio?

paragraphs.original: Yea, the same.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's me.

paragraphs.original: Come, will you go with me?
paragraphs.translated: Will you come with me?

paragraphs.original: Whither?
paragraphs.translated: Where?

paragraphs.original:
Even to the next willow, about your own business, county.
What fashion will you wear the garland of? About your
neck like an usurer's chain? Or under your arm like a
lieutenant's scarf? You must wear it one way, for the Prince
hath gat your Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
Right over to that
willow tree to see about your business. How do you want to wear your garland of willow leaves? Around your neck, like a moneylender's gold chain, or under your arm, like a lieutenant's sash? You have to wear it somehow, because the Prince has gotten your Hero.
willow tree

paragraphs.original: I wish him joy of her.
paragraphs.translated: I hope he enjoys her.

paragraphs.original:
Why, that's spoken like an honest drover; so they sell
bullocks. But did you think the Prince would have served
you thus?
paragraphs.translated: You sound like a cattle dealer: that's the way they sell bulls. But do you really think the Prince would treat you that way?

paragraphs.original: I pray you, leave me.
paragraphs.translated: Please, leave me alone.

paragraphs.original:
Ho, now you strike like the blind man. 'Twas the boy that
stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.
paragraphs.translated: Look at you, thrashing about like a blind man. A boy robbed you, but you'll beat up the post instead.

paragraphs.original: If it will not be, I'll leave you.
paragraphs.translated:
If you won't leave, then I'll leave.
I'll

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges. But that
my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The
Prince's fool! Ha, it may be I go under that title because I am
merry. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong. I am not so
reputed! It is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice
that puts the world into her person and so gives me out.
Well, I'll be revenged as I may.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, the poor bird. Now he'll hide himself in the bushes. But how strange that Beatrice should seem to know who I was and yet not know at the same time. "The Prince's fool"! Maybe they call me that because I am cheerful. Yes, but I am insulting myself by thinking this way. I don't have that kind of reputation! Beatrice's mean, sarcastic nature makes her believe that the entire world shares her opinions; that's why she describes me this way. Well, I'll get my revenge.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO enters.

paragraphs.original: Now, Signior, where's the Count? Did you see him?
paragraphs.translated: Now, sir, where is Claudio? Did you see him?

paragraphs.original:
Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame. I
found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren. I told
him, and I think I told him true, that your Grace had got the
goodwill of this young lady, and I offered him my company
to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as being
forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be
whipped.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, my lord, I played the part of a gossip and brought him the news. I found him here,
as sad as a rabbit in a burrow. I told him - and I think I was telling the truth - that you had won the lady's heart. I offered to accompany him to the willow tree, where he could either make a garland - fit to be worn by an abandoned lover - or gather sticks into a bundle, ready for his beating.
as sad as a rabbit in a burrow

paragraphs.original: To be whipped? What's his fault?
paragraphs.translated: Beating? Why, what did he do?

paragraphs.original:
The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed
with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he
steals it.
paragraphs.translated: He was like a schoolboy who finds a bird's nest and happily shows it to his friend, who then steals it from him.

paragraphs.original:
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression
is in the stealer.
paragraphs.translated: What, is trusting a friend such a crime? The criminal is the one who stole the nest.

paragraphs.original:
Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the
garland too, for the garland he might have worn himself
and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take
it, have stolen his birds' nest.
paragraphs.translated: It might have been appropriate to make both the rod and the garland. He could have worn the garland himself and beaten you with the rod, since you - as I understand it - have stolen his bird's nest.

paragraphs.original: I will but teach them to sing and restore them to the owner.
paragraphs.translated: I only want to teach the baby birds to sing; then I will return the nest to its rightful owner.

paragraphs.original:
If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say
honestly.
paragraphs.translated: We'll wait and see; if the chicks follow your lead - if Hero is ready to love Claudio - then we'll know you're telling the truth.

paragraphs.original:
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you. The gentleman
that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.
paragraphs.translated: Lady Beatrice is angry with you. The gentleman she danced with told her you insulted her.

paragraphs.original:
O, she misused me past the endurance of a block! An oak
but with one green leaf on it would have answered her. My
very visor began to assume life and scold with her. She told
me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the Prince's
jester, that I was duller than a great thaw, huddling jest
upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that I
stood like a man at a mark with a whole army shooting at
me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs. If her
breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no
living near her; she would infect to the north star. I would
not marry her, though she were endowed with all that
Adam had left him before he transgressed. She would have
made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club
to make the fire, too. Come, talk not of her. You shall find
her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God some
scholar would conjure her, for certainly, while she is here,
a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary, and people
sin upon purpose because they would go thither. So indeed
all disquiet, horror and perturbation follows her.
paragraphs.translated:
Not even a block of wood could handle her abuses! An oak tree barely clinging to life would have revived itself to fight her. Even my mask seemed to come to life in order to argue with her. She told me - not realizing it was me - that I was the Prince's jester and as dull as mud. She hurled mocking insults at me with such incredible speed that all I could do was stand there, paralyzed. She speaks daggers, and every word stabs. If her breath were as terrible as her words, she would kill every living thing from here to the furthest star. I wouldn't marry her, even if she were as blessed as paradise. If she were married to the great hero Hercules, she would have humiliated him with chores around the house and ordered him to chop up his famous club for firewood. Please, don't mention her. She's as wicked as
Ate, just disguised in pretty clothes. I wish to God that some wise man would conjure her away, because as long as she lives on earth, our lives are filled with turmoil. It's quieter in hell, where people, sinning on purpose, are eager to be sent just to get away from her. So chaos, horror, and sorrow follow her wherever she goes.
Ate

paragraphs.original: Enter CLAUDIO,BEATRICE, HERO, andLEONATO
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO, BEATRICE,HERO, and LEONATO enter.

paragraphs.original: Look, here she comes.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here she comes.

paragraphs.original:
Will your grace command me any service to the world's
end? I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes
that you can devise to send me on. I will fetch you a
toothpicker now from the furthest inch of Asia, bring you
the length of Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the
great Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pygmies,
rather than hold three words' conference with this harpy.
You have no employment for me?
paragraphs.translated:
Your highness, could you send me on a mission to the ends of the earth? I'll go to the Antipodes for any little errand you can think of. I'll fetch you a toothpick from the
farthest reaches of Asia, or find out Prester John's shoe size, or snatch a hair from Kublai Khan's beard, or deliver any message you wish to relay to the Pygmies - anything rather than exchange three words with this awful, screeching woman. Isn't there something you want from me?
farthest reaches of Asia

paragraphs.original: None but to desire your good company.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing but your good company.

paragraphs.original:
O God, sir, here's a dish I love not. I cannot endure my
Lady Tongue!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, God, sir, here comes a dish I hate. I can't stand tongue.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to BEATRICE) Come, lady, come, you have lost the heart of
(to
)
Signior Benedick.

Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave him use for
it, a double heart for his single one. Marry, once before he
won it of me with false dice. Therefore your Grace may well
say I have lost it.
paragraphs.translated: It's true, my lord. He lent it to me once, and I paid him back with interest: a double heart for his single one. Really, he won it from me once before in a dishonest game of dice. So I suppose your grace can truly say that I have lost it.

paragraphs.original: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.
paragraphs.translated: You've humiliated him, lady: you've put him down.

paragraphs.original:
So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove
the mother of fools. I have brought Count Claudio, whom
you sent me to seek.
paragraphs.translated:
And I hope that he won't
put me down or I'm sure to have fools for children.I've brought Claudio, who you sent me to find.
put me down

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, Count, wherefore are you sad?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what's wrong, count? Why are you so sad?

paragraphs.original: Not sad, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not sad, my lord.

paragraphs.original: How then, sick?
paragraphs.translated: What then, sick?

paragraphs.original: Neither, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I'm neither, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but
civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous
complexion.
paragraphs.translated: The count is neither sad nor sick nor cheerful nor well - he's just civil, as Seville as an orange, with the same jealous-yellow complexion.

paragraphs.original:
I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true, though, I'll be
sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false. - Here, Claudio, I
have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won. I have broke
with her father and his goodwill obtained. Name the day of
marriage, and God give thee joy.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, lady, I think your description is correct, though I swear he has no reason to look like that. Here, Claudio, I've wooed Hero for you, and she's agreed to marry you. I've told her father, and he's given his permission. Tell us when you wish to get married, and may God give you joy.

paragraphs.original:
Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes.
His grace hath made the match, and all grace say "Amen"
to it.
paragraphs.translated: Claudio, take my daughter, and, with her, take my fortunes. The Prince has made the match, and may God bless it.

paragraphs.original: Speak, Count, 'tis your cue.
paragraphs.translated: Speak, Claudio, that's your cue.

paragraphs.original:
Silence is the perfectest herald of joy. I were but little happy
if I could say how much. - Lady, as you are mine, I am
yours. I give away myself for you and dote upon the
exchange.
paragraphs.translated: Complete joy makes one speechless; if I were only a little happy, then I could say exactly how much. Lady, you are mine and I am yours. For you, I give myself away and I'm ecstatic about the exchange.

paragraphs.original:
Speak, cousin, or if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss
and let not him speak neither.
paragraphs.translated: Say something, cousin. Or, if you can't say anything, stop his mouth with a kiss and don't let him speak, either.

paragraphs.original: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, lady, you have a merry heart.

paragraphs.original:
Yea, my lord. I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side
of care. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord. I thank my heart - the poor fool - for it keeps away from seriousness. Look, my cousin is whispering to Claudio that she loves him.

paragraphs.original: And so she doth, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: Why, you're absolutely right, cousin.

paragraphs.original:
Good Lord for alliance! Thus goes everyone to the world
but I, and I am sunburnt. I may sit in a corner and cry,
"Heigh-ho for a husband!"
paragraphs.translated: Thank the lord for alliances! So everyone goes off into the world except me, who stays in because I'm sunburned. I should sit in the corner and sing that song, "Heigh-Ho for a Husband!"

paragraphs.original: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
paragraphs.translated: Lady Beatrice, I'll get you a husband.

paragraphs.original:
I would rather have one of your father's getting. Hath your
grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent
husbands, if a maid could come by them.
paragraphs.translated: I'd rather get a husband from your father. Don't you have any brothers like you? Your father's sons would make excellent husbands, if only a girl could catch one for herself.

paragraphs.original: Will you have me, lady?
paragraphs.translated: Will you take me, my lady?

paragraphs.original:
No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days.
Your Grace is too costly to wear every day. But I beseech
your Grace pardon me. I was born to speak all mirth and no
matter.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord, unless I could have another husband for the work week. You are too expensive to wear every day. But please, forgive me, your highness. I was born to speak cleverly, not seriously.

paragraphs.original:
Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best
becomes you, for out o' question you were born in a merry
hour.
paragraphs.translated: I'd be more offended if you were silent, for being lively and cheerful suits you best. Surely, you must have been born at a happy time.

paragraphs.original:
No, sure, my lord, my mother cried, but then there was a
star danced, and under that was I born. - Cousins, God
give you joy!
paragraphs.translated: Actually, my lord, my mother cried when she was giving birth to me. But then a star danced in the sky, and that's the moment I was born. - Kinsmen, I'm off.

paragraphs.original: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?
paragraphs.translated: Niece, will you take care of those things I mentioned?

paragraphs.original: I cry you mercy, uncle. - By your Grace's pardon.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, yes, I'm sorry, uncle. - If you'll excuse me, your grace.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, she's a very good-natured lady.

paragraphs.original:
There's little of the melancholy element in her, my lord. She
is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for
I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of
unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.
paragraphs.translated: There's very little about her that's gloomy, my lord. She's only sad when she sleeps - and not even then. Hero told me that Beatrice has often had dreams about being unhappy, and managed to wake herself from them by laughing.

paragraphs.original: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.
paragraphs.translated: She can't stand to hear about getting a husband.

paragraphs.original: Oh, by no means. She mocks all her wooers out of suit.
paragraphs.translated: No, not at all. She mocks all her suitors so severely that they drop the suit.

paragraphs.original: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.
paragraphs.translated: She would make a good wife for Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they
would talk themselves mad.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Lord, if they were married, they'd drive themselves crazy within a week.

paragraphs.original: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?
paragraphs.translated: Count Claudio, when do you plan to go to church and be married?

paragraphs.original:
Tomorrow, my lord. Time goes on crutches till love have all
his rites.
paragraphs.translated: Tomorrow, my lord. Time will move as slowly as an old man until our love receives its proper ceremony.

paragraphs.original:
Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just
sevennight, and a time too brief, too, to have all things
answer my mind.
paragraphs.translated: Wait till Monday, my dear son, which is only a week away. Even that is too short a time to plan things the way I would like.

paragraphs.original:
(to CLAUDIO) Come, you shake the head at so long a
(to
)
breathing, but I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go
dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules'
labors, which is to bring Signor Benedick and the Lady
Beatrice into a mountain of affection, th' one with th' other.
I would fain have it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion
it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall
give you direction.

My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights'
watchings.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I will help you, even if it means I have to stay awake for ten nights straight.

paragraphs.original: And I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Me too, my lord.

paragraphs.original: And you too, gentle Hero?
paragraphs.translated: And you, sweet Hero?

paragraphs.original:
I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a
good husband.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do any decent thing, my lord, to help my cousin get a good husband.

paragraphs.original:
And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband that I know.
Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, of approved
valor, and confirmed honesty. I will teach you how to humor
your cousin that she shall fall in love with Benedick. - And
I, with your two helps, will so practice on Benedick
that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he
shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no
longer an archer; his glory shall be ours, for we are the only
love gods. Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
paragraphs.translated: And Benedick is not the worst husband I can think of. This much I can say about him: he is well-born, has proven his bravery in battle, and has established his good character.
