Hero, I'll show you how to influence your cousin so she falls in love with Benedick. We men will trick Benedick so that, despite his quick wit and his queasiness about marriage, he will fall in love with her. If we can do this, then we will steal Cupid's glory. We will be the supreme love gods! Come inside with me, and I will tell you my plan.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON JOHN andBORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: Enter DON JOHN andBORACHIO

paragraphs.original:
It is so. The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of
Leonato.
paragraphs.translated: It's arranged. The Count Claudio will marry Leonato's daughter.

paragraphs.original: Yea, my lord, but I can cross it.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord, but I can spoil it.

paragraphs.original:
Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to
me. I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes
athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine. How canst
thou cross this marriage?
paragraphs.translated: Any obstacle or barrier to Claudio's happiness will be like medicine to me. I hate him so much it makes me sick, and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy. How will you wreck this marriage?

paragraphs.original:
Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty
shall appear in me.
paragraphs.translated: I can only do it by lying, my lord, but I can do it so secretly that no one will suspect me.

paragraphs.original: Show me briefly how.
paragraphs.translated: Quickly, tell me how.

paragraphs.original:
I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in
the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
paragraphs.translated: I think it was a year ago that I told you how much Margaret, Hero's servant woman, likes me.

paragraphs.original: I remember.
paragraphs.translated: I remember.

paragraphs.original:
I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her
to look out at her lady's chamber window.
paragraphs.translated: I can arrange it so that at some indecent hour of the night, she looks out Hero's bedroom window.

paragraphs.original: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?
paragraphs.translated: How will that kill this marriage?

paragraphs.original:
The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the
Prince your brother. Spare not to tell him that he hath
wronged his honor in marrying the renowned Claudio,
whose estimation do you mightily hold up, to a
contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.
paragraphs.translated: That part is up to you. Go to the Prince, your brother, and tell him that he has done a terrible thing by matching the renowned Claudio - whom you greatly admire - with such a tainted whore as Hero.

paragraphs.original: What proof shall I make of that?
paragraphs.translated: What will be my evidence?

paragraphs.original:
Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo
Hero, and kill Leonato. Look you for any other issue?
paragraphs.translated: Evidence enough to deceive the Prince, anger Claudio, ruin Hero, and kill Leonato. Is there anything else you wish?

paragraphs.original: Only to despite them, I will endeavor anything.
paragraphs.translated: That's all I want, and I'll do anything to accomplish it.

paragraphs.original:
Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the
Count Claudio alone. Tell them that you know that Hero
loves me. Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and
Claudio, as in love of your brother's honor, who hath made
this match, and his friend's reputation, who is thus like to
be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have
discovered thus. They will scarcely believe this without
trial. Offer them instances, which shall bear no less
likelihood than to see me at her chamber window, hear me
call Margaret "Hero," hear Margaret term me "Claudio,"
and bring them to see this the very night before the
intended wedding, for in the meantime I will so fashion the
matter that Hero shall be absent, and there shall appear
such seeming truth of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall
be called assurance and all the preparation overthrown.
paragraphs.translated:
Find a time to speak with Don Pedro and Claudio alone. Tell them you know that Hero loves me. Pretend to be very concerned about both the Prince, who has compromised his honor by making the match, and Claudio, whose reputation will be ruined by this woman who's pretending to be a virgin. Of course, they won't believe you without proof. Tell them you've seen the two of us at Hero's bedroom window, and then bring them to see for themselves on the night before the wedding. I'll arrange it so that Hero is away for the night, so what they'll actually see is Margaret and me at the window, calling each other "Hero" and
"Claudio." It'll be such blatant evidence of Hero's disloyalty that Claudio's jealousy will quickly turn to certainty, and the wedding will be instantly called off.
"Claudio."

paragraphs.original:
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in
practice. Be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a
thousand ducats.
paragraphs.translated: Make the arrangements, and I'll do it. Do this carefully, and I will reward you with a thousand gold coins.

paragraphs.original:
Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not
shame me.
paragraphs.translated: If you make the accusation convincingly, then my cunning won't fail me.

paragraphs.original: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go now to find out the date of the wedding.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK enters.

paragraphs.original: Boy!
paragraphs.translated: Boy!

paragraphs.original: Enter BOY
paragraphs.translated: A BOY enters.

paragraphs.original: Signior?
paragraphs.translated: Yes Signior?

paragraphs.original:
In my chamber window lies a book. Bring it hither to me in
the orchard.
paragraphs.translated: In my bedroom window there is a book. Go get it and bring it to me here in the orchard.

paragraphs.original: I am here already, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I'm already here, sir.

paragraphs.original: I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again.
paragraphs.translated: I see that you are here, but I'd like you to go there and then come back again.

paragraphs.original: Exit BOY
paragraphs.translated: The BOY exits.

paragraphs.original:
I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another
man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love, will,
after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others,
become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love - 
and such a man is Claudio. I have known when there was no
music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he
rather hear the tabor and the pipe. I have known when he
would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and
now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new
doublet. He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose,
like an honest man and a soldier, and now is he turned
orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet, just
so many strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with
these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not.
paragraphs.translated: I'm amazed that a man, after watching romance turn another man into a fool and laughing at that man, can turn right around and become the thing he's scorned. That's the kind of man Claudio is. I knew him when he listened to nothing but the military drum and fife; now he would rather hear the sweet and refined music of the tabor and pipe. I knew him when he would've walked ten miles to see a well-crafted suit of armor; now he spends ten nights awake in his room designing himself a fancy new jacket. He used to speak plainly and to the point, like an honorable man and soldier; now his speech is elaborate and flowery. His words are like a miraculous banquet, full of strange new dishes. Will I be changed like that, and see the world through a lover's eyes? I'm not sure, but I don't think so.

paragraphs.original:
I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster,
but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me,
he shall never make me such a fool. One woman is fair, yet
I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous,
yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one
woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she shall be, that's
certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen
her; fair, or I'll ever look on her; mild, or come not near
me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an
excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what color it
please God. Ha! The Prince and Monsieur Love! I will hide
me in the arbor.
paragraphs.translated: I can't promise that love won't transform me, but I can promise you this: until I truly fall in love, a woman will never make me act like such a fool. A beautiful woman comes along, but I'm unmoved. A wise woman turns up, but I'm unmoved. A virtuous woman appears, but I'm unmoved. I refuse to fall in love until all three qualities unite in a single woman. She must be rich, certainly, and smart, or I'll have nothing to do with her. She has to be virtuous, or I'll never bid on her; beautiful, or I won't bother to look at her. Mild-mannered, or else she should stay away from me. Noble, or I won't have her even if she's an angel. She must be well spoken, an excellent musician, and her hair should be - well, I suppose the color doesn't matter. Ha! Look, it's the Prince and Mr. Love. I'll hide in the arbor.

paragraphs.original: He hides
paragraphs.translated: He hides.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, and LEONATO, andBALTHASAR with music
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO enter. BALTHASAR enters with music.

paragraphs.original: Come, shall we hear this music?
paragraphs.translated: Well, should we hear some music?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,
As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord. Listen to how quiet the evening is, as if it's purposefully setting the stage for a song.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to CLAUDIO)
(aside to
)
See you where Benedick hath hid himself?
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only CLAUDIOcan hear) Do you see where Benedick is hiding?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
(aside to DON PEDRO)
(aside to
)
O, very well, my lord. The music ended,
We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only DON PEDROcan hear) Yes, very well, my lord. Once the music has ended, we'll give him more than he bargained for.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, Balthasar, let's hear that song again.

paragraphs.original:
O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
To slander music anymore than once.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my good lord, don't make me insult music again with my awful singing.

paragraphs.original:
It is the witness still of excellency
To put a strange face on his own perfection.
I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.
paragraphs.translated: You can tell an artist is excellent when he denies his own perfection. Please, sing for us; don't make me woo you anymore!

paragraphs.original:
Because you talk of wooing, I will sing,
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos,
Yet will he swear he loves.
paragraphs.translated: Since you put it that way, I'll sing. You're like a suitor who courts a woman insincerely, swearing that he loves her even though he really doesn't find her worthy.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, pray thee, come,
Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, please sing. If you'd like to continue this discussion, at least do so with music.

paragraphs.original:
Note this before my notes:
There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.
paragraphs.translated: Just know this before I begin: I can't play a single note that's worthy of note.

paragraphs.original:
Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks!
Note notes, forsooth, and nothing.
paragraphs.translated: Listen to him speaking in quarter notes! Get on with your note-playing now.

paragraphs.original: Music plays
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Now, divine air! Now is his soul ravished. Is it not
(aside)
strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men's
bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when all's done.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) That music must be divine, because their souls have been captivated. Isn't it strange that strings made of sheep's guts are capable of drawing men's souls out of their bodies? Well, I'd rather listen to a plain old hunting horn than this music, when all is said and done.
(to himself)
I'd

paragraphs.original:
(singing)
(singing)
Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,
Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more
Men were deceivers ever,
Men were deceivers ever
One foot in sea and one on shore,
One foot in sea and one on shore
To one thing constant never.
To one thing constant never
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
Then sigh not so, but let them go
And be you blithe and bonny,
And be you blithe and bonny
Converting all your sounds of woe
Converting all your sounds of woe
Into Hey, nonny nonny.
Into Hey, nonny nonny
Sing no more ditties, sing no mo
Sing no more ditties, sing no mo
Of dumps so dull and heavy.
Of dumps so dull and heavy
The fraud of men was ever so,
The fraud of men was ever so
Since summer first was leavy.
Since summer first was leavy
Then sigh not so, but let them go
Then sigh not so, but let them go
And be you blithe and bonny,
And be you blithe and bonny
Converting all your sounds of woe
Converting all your sounds of woe
Into Hey, nonny nonny.
Into Hey, nonny nonny
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
Don't cry anymore, ladies, don't cry anymore
Don't cry anymore, ladies, don't cry anymore
Men have always been deceivers,
Men have always been deceivers
One foot on a ship and one on the shore,
One foot on a ship and one on the shore
Never devoted to anything.
Never devoted to anything
So don't cry like that, just let them go
So don't cry like that, just let them go
And be happy and carefree forever,
And be happy and carefree forever
Turning all your sad sounds around
Turning all your sad sounds around
When you sing "Hey, nonny nonny" instead.
When you sing "Hey, nonny nonny" instead
Don't sing more sad songs
Don't sing more sad songs
About being down in the dumps
About being down in the dumps
For men have been committing this kind of fraud
For men have been committing this kind of fraud
Ever since the first summer trees had leaves.
Ever since the first summer trees had leaves
So don't cry like that, just let them go
So don't cry like that, just let them go
And be happy and carefree forever,
And be happy and carefree forever
Turning all your sad sounds around
Turning all your sad sounds around
When you sing "Hey, nonny nonny" instead.
When you sing "Hey, nonny nonny" instead

paragraphs.original: By my troth, a good song.
paragraphs.translated: That's a good song.

paragraphs.original: And an ill singer, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: And a bad singer, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Ha, no, no, faith, thou sing'st well enough for a shift.
paragraphs.translated: Ha! No, no, really, your voice is good enough in a pinch.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,
(aside)
they would have hanged him. And I pray God his bad voice
bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the night raven,
come what plague could have come after it.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) If a dog had howled like that, I would have hung it. I hope his horrible singing doesn't have any ill effects. I would've rather listened to the night raven screech, even if the bird's noise does give me the plague, as they say it will.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee, get us
some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it
at the Lady Hero's chamber window
paragraphs.translated: Yes, do you hear me, Balthasar? Please, get some excellent music, because tomorrow we want to serenade Lady Hero at her bedroom window.

paragraphs.original: The best I can, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do the best I can, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Do so. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Please do. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR exits.

paragraphs.original:
Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of today,
that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Leonato. What was it that you told me today - that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, ay. (aside to DON PEDRO) Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl
(aside to
)
sits. - I did never think that lady would have loved any
man.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh yes. (speaking so that only DON PEDRO can hear) Go on, keep walking: our prey is in sight. - I never thought that woman would love any man.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
No, nor I neither, but most wonderful that she should so
dote on Signor Benedick, whom she hath in all outward
behaviors seemed ever to abhor.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't, either. But how wonderful that she should be so fond of Signior Benedick, whom she has always appeared to hate.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Is 't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Is it possible? Is that the way the wind is blowing?
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it, but
that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the
infinite of thought.
paragraphs.translated: Really, my lord, I don't know what to make of it, but she loves him with such a passion that it's past all understanding.

paragraphs.original: May be she doth but counterfeit.
paragraphs.translated: Maybe she's just pretending.

paragraphs.original: Faith, like enough.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's quite likely.

paragraphs.original:
O God! Counterfeit? There was never counterfeit of
passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God! Pretending? No one has ever faked passion as skillfully as this, then.

paragraphs.original: Why, what effects of passion shows she?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what symptoms of love does she exhibit?

(speaking so that only LEONATOcan hear) Bait the hook well; this fish is going to bite.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
What effects, my lord? She will sit you - you heard my
daughter tell you how.
paragraphs.translated: What symptoms, my lord? She will have a seat - you heard my daughter tell you how.

paragraphs.original: She did indeed.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, she did tell us.

paragraphs.original:
How, how I pray you? You amaze me. I would have thought
her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.
paragraphs.translated: Please, please tell me! This is amazing. I would have thought she was invincible against any assault of love.

paragraphs.original:
I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against
Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: I would have sworn that, too, my lord, especially against Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I should think this a gull but that the white-bearded
(aside)
fellow speaks it. Knavery cannot, sure, hide himself in such
reverence.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I would take this as a joke if the old man weren't saying it. Mischief surely can't be hiding in such a respectable man.
(to himself)

(speaking so that only DON PEDROcan hear) We've infected him! Keep it up.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
paragraphs.translated: Has she told Benedick how she feels?

paragraphs.original: No, and swears she never will. That's her torment.
paragraphs.translated: No, and she swears she never will. That's what's driving her crazy.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis true indeed, so your daughter says. "Shall I," says she,
"that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him
that I love him?"
paragraphs.translated: It's true, Hero says so. Beatrice asks, "Does it make any sense to write and tell him I love him when I have always treated him with scorn?"

paragraphs.original:
This says she now when she is beginning to write to him, for
she'll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her
smock till she have writ a sheet of paper. My daughter tells
us all.
paragraphs.translated: She says this as she begins to write the letter. She'll be getting up twenty times in a night, sitting there in her slip until she's written a page. My daughter told me everything.

paragraphs.original:
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest
your daughter told.
paragraphs.translated: Now that you speak of paper, I remember a funny story of Hero's.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found
"Benedick" and "Beatrice" between the sheet?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you mean when Beatrice writes a letter and Hero sees that it has "Benedick" and "Beatrice" written all over it?

paragraphs.original: That.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's the one.

paragraphs.original:
O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at
herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that
she knew would flout her. "I measure him," says she, "by
my own spirit, for I should flout him if he writ to me, yea,
though I love him, I should."
paragraphs.translated: Oh, she tears that letter into a thousand small pieces and berates herself for being so forward as to write a letter to a man she knows would mock her. "I compare him," she says, "to myself, and I know that I would mock him if he wrote me such a letter. Yes, even though I love him, I would mock him."

paragraphs.original:
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her
heart, tears her hair, prays, curses: "O sweet Benedick! God
give me patience!"
paragraphs.translated: Then she falls down to her knees, weeps, sobs, beats her breast, tears her hair, prays, and curses: "Oh sweet Benedick! God give me patience!"

paragraphs.original:
She doth indeed, my daughter says so, and the ecstasy hath
so much overborne her that my daughter is sometime
afeared
she will do a desperate outrage to herself. It is very true.
paragraphs.translated: She did indeed, my daughter says so. She worries that Beatrice is so overwrought that she might do herself harm someday. It's true.

paragraphs.original:
It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she
will not discover it.
paragraphs.translated: If she won't tell Benedick, someone else should.

paragraphs.original:
To what end? He would make but a sport of it and torment
the poor lady worse.
paragraphs.translated: And what would that accomplish? He'll just turn it into a joke and torment the poor woman even more.

paragraphs.original:
An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an
excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is
virtuous.
paragraphs.translated: If he did that, it would be a charitable deed to hang him. She's an excellent, sweet woman, and there's no doubt that she is virtuous.

paragraphs.original: And she is exceeding wise.
paragraphs.translated: And she is very smart.

paragraphs.original: In every thing but in loving Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: Except for the fact that she loves Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a
body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.
I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and
her guardian.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my lord, when wisdom and passion are in one body, it's ten to one that the passion will win. I am sorry for her, as I should be, since I am both her uncle and her guardian.

paragraphs.original:
I would she had bestowed this dotage on me. I would have
daffed all other respects and made her half myself. I pray
you tell Benedick of it and hear what he will say.
paragraphs.translated: I wish she were in love with me instead. I would have thrown away all other considerations and made her my wife. Please, tell Benedick about her feelings and see what he has to say.

paragraphs.original: Were it good, think you?
paragraphs.translated: Is that a good idea, do you think?

paragraphs.original:
Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he
love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known,
and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one
breath of her accustomed crossness.
paragraphs.translated: Hero thinks Beatrice will surely die, for she says she'll die if he doesn't love her, and that she'll die before she tells him, and she'll die if he woos her and she's made to hold back even one of her usual insults.

paragraphs.original:
She doth well. If she should make tender of her love, 'tis
very possible he'll scorn it, for the man, as you know all,
hath a contemptible spirit.
paragraphs.translated: She's probably right. If she offers him her love, it's very possible that he'll scorn it, since, as we all know, he tends to be contemptuous.

paragraphs.original: He is a very proper man.
paragraphs.translated: He's a very proper man.

paragraphs.original: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, he is good-looking and carries himself well.

paragraphs.original: Before God, and in my mind, very wise.
paragraphs.translated: And I swear to God he's very smart.

paragraphs.original: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
paragraphs.translated: He does indeed show sparks of something like wit.

paragraphs.original: And I take him to be valiant.
paragraphs.translated: And I believe him to be brave.

paragraphs.original:
As Hector, I assure you, and in the managing of quarrels
you may say he is wise, for either he avoids them with great
discretion or undertakes them with a most Christian-like
fear.
paragraphs.translated:
As brave as
Hector, surely. And you could say that he is wise in managing fights, for he either avoids them discreetly or enters into them timidly.
Hector

paragraphs.original:
If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace. If he
break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear
and trembling.
paragraphs.translated: If he fears God, he must necessarily keep the peace. If he breaks the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.

paragraphs.original:
And so will he do, for the man doth fear God, howsoever it
seems not in him by some large jests he will make. Well, I
am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell
him of her love?
paragraphs.translated: And he'll do that, because he's a God-fearing man, even though his joking makes it seem otherwise. Well, I'm sorry for your niece. Should we go find Benedick and tell him about Beatrice's love?

paragraphs.original:
Never tell him, my lord, let her wear it out with good
counsel.
paragraphs.translated: No, don't ever tell him, my lord. Let her get over it, with the help of good advice.

paragraphs.original: Nay, that's impossible. She may wear her heart out first.
paragraphs.translated: No, that's impossible. Her heart will break first.

paragraphs.original:
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter. Let it cool
the while. I love Benedick well, and I could wish he would
modestly examine himself to see how much he is unworthy
so good a lady.
paragraphs.translated: Well, we'll hear more about it from your daughter. Let it sit for a while. I am very fond of Benedick, and I just wish he would take a look at himself and realize how unfairly he's treating this good woman.

paragraphs.original: My lord, will you walk? Dinner is ready.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, will you come with me? Dinner is ready.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to DON PEDRO and LEONATO) If he do not dote on her
(aside to
and
)
upon this, I will never trust my expectation.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only DON PEDROand LEONATO can hear) If he doesn't fall in love with her now, I'll never trust my intuition again.
(speaking so that only
and
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
(aside to LEONATO) Let there be the same net spread for her,
(aside to
)
and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry.
The sport will be when they hold one an opinion of
another's dotage, and no such matter. That's the scene that
I would see, which will be merely a dumb show. Let us send
her to call him in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only LEONATOcan hear) The same trap must be set for her; that's your daughter's and servants' job. The real fun will be when they both believe the other to be in love, without any of it being true. I can't wait to watch that drama - it'll be a pantomime, since both of them will be totally speechless! Let's send Beatrice to call Benedick in to dinner
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except BENEDICK exits.

paragraphs.original:
(coming forward) This can be no trick. The conference was
(coming forward)
sadly borne; they have the truth of this from Hero; they
seem to pity the lady. It seems her affections have their full
bent. Love me? Why, it must be requited! I hear how I am
censured. They sy I will bear myself proudly if I perceive
the love come from her. They say, too, that she will rather
die than give any sign of affection. I did never think to
marry. I must not seem proud. Happy are they that hear
their detractions and can put them to mending. They say
the lady is fair; 'tis a truth, I can bear them witness. And
virtuous; 'tis so, I cannot reprove it. And wise, but for
loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no
great argument of her folly, for I will be horribly in love
with her! I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants
of wit broken on me because I have railed so long against
marriage, but doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the
meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age. Shall
quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the
brain awe a man from the career of his humor?
No! The world must be peopled. When I said I would die a
bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married.
Here comes Beatrice. By this day, she's a fair lady. I do spy
some marks of love in her.
paragraphs.translated:
(coming forward) This can't be a trick. They spoke with great seriousness, and they have Hero's testimony. They seem to pity the lady. It seems her love is stretched to the limit. She loves me? Well, that love must be returned! I hear how I'm criticized. They say I'll be smug if I find out she loves me. They also say she'd rather die than give any sign of her feelings. I never thought I'd marry. I can't appear to be proud. People who discover their faults and can then change them are lucky indeed. They say the lady is beautiful; it's true, I've seen it myself. And virtuous; that's true, I can't disprove that. And smart, except that she loves me. That may not be any proof of her intelligence, but I swear it won't be evidence of her stupidity - for I'm going to be horribly in love with her! People might tease me here and there, since I attacked marriage for so long. But don't tastes change? A man can love a dish when he is young that he hates when he turns old. Will quips and clever remarks and scathing written words keep a man from getting what his heart desires? No! The world needs to be populated. When I said that I'd die as a bachelor, I just meant that I didn't think I'd live until I got married. Here comes Beatrice. By God! She's a beautiful lady. I think I sense some signs of love in her.
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters.

paragraphs.original: Against my will, I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: Against my will, I've been told to bring you in to dinner.

paragraphs.original: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
paragraphs.translated: Lovely Beatrice, I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that.

paragraphs.original:
I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to
thank me. If it had been painful, I would not have come.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me. If the job had been painful, I would not have come.

paragraphs.original: You take pleasure then in the message?
paragraphs.translated: So you took pleasure in bringing me this message?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's point and
choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, Signior. Fare you
well.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, as much pleasure as one might take in choking a bird at knifepoint. You don't want to eat, sir? Goodbye, then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
Ha! "Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to
dinner." There's a double meaning in that. "I took no more
pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me."
That's as much as to say, "Any pains that I take for you is as
easy as thanks." If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.
If I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.
paragraphs.translated:
Ha! "Against my will, I've been told to bring you in to dinner." There's a double meaning in that. "I didn't take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me." That's like saying, "Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying ‘thank you.'" If this doesn't move me to take pity on her, I'm a horrible person. If I don't love her, I'm completely
hard-hearted. I will go get her picture.
hard-hearted

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter HERO,MARGARET, and URSULA
paragraphs.translated: HERO, MARGARET, andURSULA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.
Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her. Say that thou overheardst us,
And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower
Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun
Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it. There will she hide her
To listen our propose. This is thy office.
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
paragraphs.translated: Margaret, run into the sitting room. You'll find Beatrice there, talking to Claudio and the Prince. Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we're talking all about her. Tell her you heard us, and that she should sneak into the arbor where the crisscrossing branches overhead keep the honeysuckles out of the sun. (The same honeysuckles that were once ripened in the sun; they're like courtiers who rise because the king favors them, then plot to overthrow his Majesty.) She can hide there and eavesdrop on our conversation. This is your job. Do it well, and then leave us.

paragraphs.original: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.
paragraphs.translated: I'll make her come right away, I promise you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit.
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hearsay.
paragraphs.translated: All right Ursula, as Beatrice arrives, we'll be walking up and down this alley and speaking about nothing but Benedick. Whenever I mention him, praise him more than any man deserves. It'll be my job to talk about how Benedick is sick with love for Beatrice. We'll make our arrows the same way Cupid does: with gossip and rumor.

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE, behind
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters, behind.

paragraphs.original:
Now begin,
For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.
paragraphs.translated: Let's start. See, Beatrice has run over like a little bird, keeping close to the ground and trying to overhear us.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to HERO)
(aside to
)
The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream
And greedily devour the treacherous bait.
So angle we for Beatrice, who even now
Is couchèd in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only HERO can hear) The best part of fishing is watching the fish cut through the water and greedily take the bait. Now we're fishing for Beatrice, who's hiding right now in the honeysuckle arbor. Don't worry, I'll do my part.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
(aside to URSULA)
(aside to
)
Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. - 
(approaching the bower)
(approaching the bower)
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful.
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only URSULAcan hear) Then let's get closer, so she can hear all the false, sweet bait we're setting for her. -  (approaching the bower) No, truly, Ursula, she's too scornful. She's as devious and fierce as the wild hawks on the rocks.
(speaking so that only
can hear)
(approaching the bower)

paragraphs.original:
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
paragraphs.translated: But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice that much?

paragraphs.original: So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
paragraphs.translated: That's what the Prince and my fiancé say.

paragraphs.original: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
paragraphs.translated: And did they ask you to tell Beatrice about this, madam?

paragraphs.original:
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it,
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
paragraphs.translated: They did want me to tell her, but I persuaded them that, if they truly loved Benedick, they would try to get him to battle his emotions and keep Beatrice in the dark.

paragraphs.original:
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
paragraphs.translated: Why did you do that? Doesn't Benedick deserve as much luck with a mate as he would have with Beatrice?

paragraphs.original:
O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man,
But Nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice.
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprizing what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak. She cannot love
Nor take no shape nor project of affection
She is so self-endeared.
paragraphs.translated: By the god of love, I know that he deserves all that a man might possess. But Nature never made a woman's heart as proud and tough as Beatrice's. There is scorn and disdain in her eyes, and those sparkling eyes despise everything they look upon. She values her wit more highly than anything else, which looks weak by comparison. She's so in love with herself, she's incapable of loving anyone else. She can't even imagine what "love" is.

paragraphs.original:
Sure, I think so,
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, you're right. It would be bad if she knew about Benedick's love and teased him about it.

It's true. Whenever she meets a man - no matter how wise, noble, young, handsome - she rearranges all his good qualities so they end up looking bad. If he has a fair complexion, she'll say the pretty man should be her sister, not her husband. If he's dark-skinned, Nature must have spilled some ink while drawing his foolish face. If he's tall, she'll say he's a spear topped by an odd head; if he's short, she says he looks like a badly carved miniature. If he's talkative, he's a weathervane, moving in all directions at once; if he's silent, he's a block that can't be moved at all. And so she turns men inside out and never acknowledges the integrity and merit that a man has.

paragraphs.original: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.
paragraphs.translated: It's true, her nitpicking is hardly admirable.

paragraphs.original:
No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air. O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
paragraphs.translated: No, it certainly is not admirable to be so perverse and eccentric. But who would dare tell her? If I said something, she'd mock me so mercilessly that I'd probably disintegrate into air. She'd laugh me right out of my body and kill me with her wit.

paragraphs.original:
Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.
paragraphs.translated: So Benedick should conceal his emotions. Like a fire that gets covered up, Benedick should smother his love and waste away. It would be better to die that way than to die from being mocked, which is as bad as being killed by tickling.

paragraphs.original: Yet tell her of it. Hear what she will say.
paragraphs.translated: But you should tell her about this, and hear what she has to say.

paragraphs.original:
No, rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion;
And truly I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with. One doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.
paragraphs.translated: No, instead I'll go to Benedick and advise him to fight his emotions. I'll make up some awful things about my cousin and ruin her reputation. You don't know how quickly affection can be killed with a single nasty word.

paragraphs.original:
O, do not do your cousin such a wrong!
She cannot be so much without true judgment,
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have, as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, don't injure your cousin like that! With the quick, intelligent wit she's rumored to have, she can't really be such a bad judge of character that she'd refuse a man as exceptional as Signior Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted my dear Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: He's the only worthy man in Italy, aside from my dear Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy. Signor Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valor,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.
paragraphs.translated: Don't be angry with me for speaking my mind, but throughout Italy, Benedick is considered the best man in looks, bearing, intelligence, and bravery.

paragraphs.original: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.
paragraphs.translated: True, he has an excellent reputation.

paragraphs.original:
His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?
paragraphs.translated: And he deserves it, having been excellent before he had a reputation for it. When are you getting married, madam?

paragraphs.original:
Why, every day, tomorrow. Come, go in.
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: Tomorrow, and then every day after that. Come on, let's go inside. I want to show you some clothing, so you can tell me what I should wear tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: They move aside from the bower
paragraphs.translated: They move away from the bower.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to HERO)
(aside to
)
She's limed, I warrant you. We have caught her, madam.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only HERO can hear) We caught her in our trap, madam, I'm sure of it.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

(speaking so that only URSULAcan hear) If so, then you never know where love will come from. Cupid gets some lovers with arrows, but some he lays traps for!
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt HERO andURSULA
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but BEATRICE exits.

paragraphs.original:
(coming forward)
(coming forward)
What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemned for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand.
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band.
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.
paragraphs.translated:
(coming forward) I'm burning up with shame! Can this be true? Do people criticize me this much for being proud and scornful? Then I'll say goodbye to my contempt and my pride in being unmarried! No good is spoken of such a person as me behind her back. Benedick, keep on loving me and I will return your love, like a wild hawk being tamed by her handler. I'll be kind to you from now on, and if you really do love me, that kindness will encourage you to seal our love with a wedding band. People say that you deserve my love, and I believe it - not just because they've said so.
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO BENEDICK, and LEONATO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO,BENEDICK, and LEONATO enter.

paragraphs.original:
I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go
I toward Aragon.
paragraphs.translated: I'll stay in Messina until you're married, and then I'll go to Aragon.

paragraphs.original: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll vouchsafe me.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go with you, my lord, if you'll allow me.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your
marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to
wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company,
for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all
mirth. He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bow-string, and
the little hangman dare not shoot at him. He hath a heart as
sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his
heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
paragraphs.translated: No, taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it. I'll ask only Benedick to come with me, for from the top of his head to the soles of his feet he's a joker. He's evaded love once or twice, and since then Cupid doesn't dare to shoot at him. Benedick's heart is like a bell, with his tongue as the clapper: everything his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

paragraphs.original: Gallants, I am not as I have been.
paragraphs.translated: Gentleman, I am not the same man I was before.

paragraphs.original: So say I. Methinks you are sadder.
paragraphs.translated: I agree. I think you seem more serious.

paragraphs.original: I hope he be in love.
paragraphs.translated: I hope he's in love.

paragraphs.original:
Hang him, truant! There's no true drop of blood in him to
be truly touched with love. If he be sad, he wants money.
paragraphs.translated: Come off it, man! There isn't a single drop of sincerity in him that could be touched with love. If he looks serious, he must need money.

paragraphs.original: I have the toothache.
paragraphs.translated:
I have a
toothache.
toothache

paragraphs.original: Draw it.
paragraphs.translated:
Draw it.
Draw it.

paragraphs.original: Hang it!
paragraphs.translated:
Hang it!
Hang it!

paragraphs.original: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.
paragraphs.translated:
You have to hang it first. Then you can
draw it.
draw

paragraphs.original: What, sigh for the toothache?
paragraphs.translated: What, are you moaning on about your toothache?

paragraphs.original: Where is but a humor or a worm.
paragraphs.translated:
It could only have been caused by some humor or
worm.
worm

paragraphs.original: Well, everyone can master a grief but he that has it.
paragraphs.translated: Well, everyone knows how to overcome an injury except the one who actually has one.

paragraphs.original: Yet say I, he is in love.
paragraphs.translated: I repeat, he's in love.

paragraphs.original:
There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy
that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman
today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two
countries at once, as a German from the waist downward,
all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet.
Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath,
he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.
paragraphs.translated: No, there's no love in him, unless you mean his love for strange costumes. He's a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, and sometimes wears the clothing of two countries at once: a German from the waist down, with his baggy pants, and a Spaniard from the hips up, with a cloak and no jacket. Unless you're talking about his love for this kind of foolishness - which, judging from his appearance, he has - he is no fool for love, as you pretend.

paragraphs.original:
If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing
old signs. He brushes his hat o' mornings. What should
that bode?
paragraphs.translated: If he's not in love with a woman, then you can't trust the usual symptoms. He brushes his hat in the mornings. What do you think that means?

paragraphs.original: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?
paragraphs.translated: Has any man seen him at the barber's?

paragraphs.original:
No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him, and the
old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.
paragraphs.translated:
No, but the barber's assistant has been seen with him. The beard that used to decorate Benedick's cheeks has been shaved off and is now stuffing
tennis balls.
tennis balls

paragraphs.original: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.
paragraphs.translated: Getting rid of the beard definitely makes him look younger.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, he rubs himself with civet. Can you smell him out by
that?
paragraphs.translated: And he's rubbed himself with perfume. Can you smell out his secret now?

paragraphs.original: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.
paragraphs.translated: That's as good as proof that the sweet young man's in love.

paragraphs.original: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.
paragraphs.translated: The biggest clue is his seriousness.

paragraphs.original: And when was he wont to wash his face?
paragraphs.translated: And when has he ever been known to wash his face?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, or to paint himself? For the which I hear what they say
of him.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, or to wear cosmetics? I hear what they say about him for doing that.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute
string and now governed by stops -
paragraphs.translated:
Indeed, his mocking spirit has now crawled into a
lute, and he can be played like an instrument - 
lute

paragraphs.original:
Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him. Conclude, conclude,
he is in love.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, it all adds up to a serious story for Benedick. A conclusion, a conclusion: he is in love.

paragraphs.original: Nay, but I know who loves him.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, and I know who loves him.

paragraphs.original: That would I know too. I warrant, one that knows him not.
paragraphs.translated: I bet I know, too: someone who clearly doesn't know him at all.

paragraphs.original:
Yes, and his ill conditions, and, in despite of all, dies for
him.
paragraphs.translated: No, she does know him, and she also knows all his bad qualities - and in spite of all this, she still dies for him.

paragraphs.original: She shall be buried with her face upwards.
paragraphs.translated: She'll be buried with her face upwards, then.

paragraphs.original:
Yet is this no charm for the toothache. - Old Signior, walk
aside with me. I have studied eight or nine wise words to
speak to you, which these hobbyhorses must not hear.
Exeunt BENEDICK andLEONATO
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK and LEONATO exit.

paragraphs.original: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice!
paragraphs.translated: I bet my life he's gone to speak with Leonato about Beatrice!

paragraphs.original:
'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their
parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one
another when they meet.
paragraphs.translated: It must be. By now, Hero and Margaret have done their part with Beatrice. The two bears won't bite each other the next time they meet.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON JOHN
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN enters.

paragraphs.original: My lord and brother, God save you.
paragraphs.translated: My lord and brother, God save you.

paragraphs.original: Good e'en, brother.
paragraphs.translated: Good evening, brother.

paragraphs.original: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: If you don't mind, I'd like to speak with you.

paragraphs.original: In private?
paragraphs.translated: In private?

paragraphs.original:
If it please you. Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I
would speak of concerns him.
paragraphs.translated: If you wish. But Count Claudio can stay, for what I'm about to say concerns him.

paragraphs.original: What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original: You know he does.
paragraphs.translated: You know that he does.

paragraphs.original: I know not that, when he knows what I know.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know that, once he knows what I know.

paragraphs.original: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.
paragraphs.translated: If there's any reason we shouldn't get married, I urge you to tell me.

paragraphs.original:
You may think I love you not. Let that appear hereafter, and
aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my
brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart
hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage - surely suit ill
spent and labor ill bestowed.
paragraphs.translated: You may think that I don't love you. I hope that, after I tell you my news, you will think better of me. My brother thinks highly of you, and because of his affection, has helped arrange your marriage - but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy.

paragraphs.original: Why, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for
she has been too long a-talking of, the lady is disloyal.
paragraphs.translated: I came here to tell you - I'll make this short, since she's already been talked about for too long - the lady is unfaithful.

paragraphs.original: Who, Hero?
paragraphs.translated: Who, Hero?

paragraphs.original: Even she: Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.
paragraphs.translated: That's the one: Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.

paragraphs.original: Disloyal?
paragraphs.translated: Unfaithful?

paragraphs.original:
The word is too good to paint out her wickedness. I could
say she were worse. Think you of a worse title, and I will fit
her to it. Wonder not till further warrant. Go but with me
tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even
the night before her wedding day. If you love her then,
tomorrow wed her. But it would better fit your honor to
change your mind.
paragraphs.translated: The word is too good to represent her wickedness. She is worse than wicked. If you can think of a more awful title, I'll call her that. But don't keep wondering without more proof. Come with me tonight, and you'll see a man enter her bedroom chamber - even tonight, the night before her wedding. If you still love her after that, then marry her tomorrow. But you would be more honorable if you changed your mind.

paragraphs.original: I will not think it.
paragraphs.translated: I won't consider it.

paragraphs.original:
If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know.
If you will follow me, I will show you enough, and when
you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.
paragraphs.translated: If you won't risk coming to see her tonight, then don't claim to know what she's like. If you follow me, I'll give you all the proof you need. Once you have seen more and heard more, then you can decide what to do.

paragraphs.original:
If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her,
tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there
will I shame her.
paragraphs.translated: If I see anything tonight that convinces me not to marry her, I'll shame her tomorrow in the very congregation where I would have married her.

paragraphs.original:
And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee
to disgrace her.
paragraphs.translated: And since I wooed her in your name, I'll join you in disgracing her.

paragraphs.original:
I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses.
Bear it coldly but till midnight and let the issue show itself.
paragraphs.translated: I won't say anything else about her until you two see things for yourselves. Remain calm until midnight, and then you'll see what the trouble is.

paragraphs.original: O day untowardly turned!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, this day has turned into a disaster!

paragraphs.original: O mischief strangely thwarting!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, mischief has ruined our plans!

paragraphs.original:
O plague right well prevented! So will you say when you
have seen the sequel.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, a plague has been prevented, thank God! That's what you'll say once you've seen part two.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DOGBERRY andVERGES with the Watch
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY and VERGES with several of the Prince's
WATCHMEN enter.

paragraphs.original: Are you good men and true?
paragraphs.translated: Are you all good and honest men?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation,
body and soul.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes they are, otherwise it would be proper for them to suffer
salvation, body and soul.
salvation

paragraphs.original:
Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they
should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the
Prince's watch.
paragraphs.translated:
If they had any
allegiance when they were chosen for the Prince's watch, a punishment like that would be too good for them.
allegiance

paragraphs.original: Well, give them their charge, neighbor Dogberry.
paragraphs.translated: Well, give them their assignment, Sir Dogberry.

paragraphs.original: First, who think you the most desartless man to be constable?
paragraphs.translated:
First, which man do you think is most
desertless to be leader of the watch?
desertless

paragraphs.original:
Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole, for they can write
and read.
paragraphs.translated: Either Hugh Otecake, sir, or else George Seacole, because both of them can read and write.

paragraphs.original:
Come hither, neighbor Seacole. God hath blessed you with
a good name. To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune,
but to write and read comes by nature.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Sir Seacole. God has blessed you with a good name. To be good-looking is a matter of luck, but to read and write is a natural gift.

paragraphs.original: Both which, Master Constable -
paragraphs.translated: Both of which, master constable -

paragraphs.original:
You have. I knew it would be your answer. Well, for your
favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it,
and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there
is no need of such vanity. You are thought here to be the
most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch;
therefore bear you the lantern. This is your charge:
paragraphs.translated:
You have. I knew that would be your answer. Well, for your good looks, sir, thank God and don't boast about it. As for your reading and writing, use those skills when you can't use your looks. You're thought to be the most
senseless and fit man here, so you will carry the lantern and be constable. This is your assignment:
senseless

paragraphs.original:
you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bid any
man stand, in the Prince's name.
paragraphs.translated:
you will
comprehend any vagrant men you see. You are to order all men to stop, in the Prince's name.
comprehend

paragraphs.original: How if he will not stand?
paragraphs.translated: And what if he won't stop?

paragraphs.original:
Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go and
presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God
you are rid of a knave.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, don't bother with him and let him go. Then immediately call the rest of the watch together and thank God that you've gotten rid of such a criminal.

paragraphs.original:
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the
Prince's subjects.
paragraphs.translated: If he won't stop when he's told to, then he isn't one of the Prince's subjects.

paragraphs.original:
True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince's
subjects. - You shall also make no noise in the streets; for,
for the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable and not
to be endured.
paragraphs.translated:
True, and you aren't supposed to meddle with anyone but the Prince's subjects. You will also stay quiet in the streets, for a babbling watch is most
tolerable and will not be endured.
tolerable

paragraphs.original:
We will rather sleep than talk. We know what belongs to a
watch.
paragraphs.translated: We'll sleep instead of talk. We know what's appropriate for a watch.

paragraphs.original:
Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman,
for I cannot see how sleeping should offend. Only have a
care that your bills be not stolen. Well, you are to call at all
the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.
paragraphs.translated: Why, you speak like an experienced and quiet watchman. Sleeping on the watch shouldn't be a problem; just make sure that your weapons don't get stolen. Also, you're supposed to visit all the bars and tell anyone who's drunk to go home and go to bed.

paragraphs.original: How if they will not?
paragraphs.translated: And what if they won't go?

paragraphs.original:
Why, then, let them alone till they are sober. If they make
you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the
men you took them for.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, leave them alone until they're sober. If even then they don't answer to your satisfaction, you can say that they're not the men you thought they were.

paragraphs.original: Well, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Very good, sir.

paragraphs.original:
If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your
office, to be no true man, and for such kind of men, the less
you meddle or make with them, why the more is for your
honesty.
paragraphs.translated: If you meet a thief, you can expect him to be dishonest. The less you have to do with that kind of man, the more honest you will be.

paragraphs.original: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?
paragraphs.translated: So if we know that a man is a thief, should we try to arrest him?

paragraphs.original:
Truly, by your office you may, but I think they that touch
pitch will be defiled. The most peaceable way for you, if
you
do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is and steal
out of your company.
paragraphs.translated:
Your position permits you to, but I think that those who stick their hands in
pitch get their hands dirty. If you encounter a thief, I think the most peaceable thing to do is to let him be himself - and steal away.
pitch

paragraphs.original: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.
paragraphs.translated: You have always been known as a merciful man, partner.

paragraphs.original:
Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man
who hath any honesty in him.
paragraphs.translated:
Truly, I wouldn't even hang a dog, much
more a man who has any honesty in him.
more

paragraphs.original:
(to the Watch) If you hear a child cry in the night, you must
(to the Watch)
call to the nurse and bid her still it.
paragraphs.translated:
(to the watchmen) If you hear a child crying in the night, you should call the nurse and tell her to quiet the child.
(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?
paragraphs.translated: What if the nurse is asleep and doesn't hear us?

paragraphs.original:
Why then, depart in peace and let the child wake her with
crying, for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas
will never answer a calf when he bleats.
paragraphs.translated:
Well then, leave quietly, and let the child's crying wake up the nurse. The ewe that doesn't go to her lamb when it baas will never tend to another animal's child.
baas

paragraphs.original: 'Tis very true.
paragraphs.translated: That's very true.

paragraphs.original:
This is the end of the charge. You, constable, are to present
the Prince's own person. If you meet the Prince in the night,
you may stay him.
paragraphs.translated: And that's the end of your assignment. You, constable, are representing the Prince himself. If you meet the Prince in the night, you can order him to stop.

paragraphs.original: Nay, by 'r Lady, that I think he cannot.
paragraphs.translated: No, by our Lady, I don't think he can.

paragraphs.original:
Five shillings to one on 't, with any man that knows the
statutes, he may stay him - marry, not without the Prince
be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man,
and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
paragraphs.translated: I'll bet any man who knows the law five shillings to one on it. Truly though, you can't stop the Prince without the Prince's consent, for the watch shouldn't offend anyone, and it's an offense to keep a man without his consent.

paragraphs.original: By 'r lady, I think it be so.
paragraphs.translated: By our Lady, I think that's true.

paragraphs.original:
Ha, ha, ha! - Well, masters, good night.
An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me. Keep your fellows'
counsels and your own; and good night. - Come, neighbor.
paragraphs.translated: Ha, ha, ha! Well, gentlemen, good night. And if anything important happens, find me and let me know. Keep each other's secrets and your own. Good night. Come, friend.

paragraphs.original:
Well, masters, we hear our charge. Let us go sit here upon
the church bench till two, and then all to bed.
paragraphs.translated: Well gentlemen, we've heard our assignment. Let's sit here on the church bench until two and then go off to bed.

paragraphs.original:
One word more, honest neighbors. I pray you watch about
Signior Leonato's door, for the wedding being there
tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight. Adieu, be vigitant,
I beseech you.
paragraphs.translated:
One more thing, good gentlemen. Watch over Signior Leonato's house; with the wedding being held there tomorrow, there's a great to-do there tonight. Adieu. Be
vigitant, I beg you.
vigitant

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DOGBERRY andVERGES
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY and VERGES exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BORACHIO andCONRADE
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO and CONRADE enter.

paragraphs.original: What Conrade!
paragraphs.translated: Conrade!

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Peace! Stir not.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(whispering) Quiet! Don't move!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original: Conrade, I say!
paragraphs.translated: Conrade, I say!

paragraphs.original: Here, man. I am at thy elbow.
paragraphs.translated: I'm here, man, at your elbow.

paragraphs.original:
Mass, and my elbow itched, I thought there would a scab
follow.
paragraphs.translated: Come to think of it, I thought I felt a scab there.

paragraphs.original:
I will owe thee an answer for that. And now forward with
thy tale.
paragraphs.translated: I'll get you for that. Now get on with your story.

paragraphs.original:
Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles
rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.
paragraphs.translated: Since it's drizzling, stand under this overhang with me and, like a true drunk, I'll tell you everything.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Some treason, masters. Yet stand close.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only the other WATCHMEN can hear) There's some treason occurring, gentlemen. Stay here.
(speaking so that only the other
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand
ducats.
paragraphs.translated: You should know I've earned a thousand gold pieces from Don John.

paragraphs.original: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?
paragraphs.translated: Is it possible that any crime could be so valuable?

paragraphs.original:
Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy
should be so rich. For when rich villains have need of poor
ones, poor ones may make what price they will.
paragraphs.translated: You should ask instead if it's possible that any criminal could be so rich. Because when rich villains need poor villains' services, those poor ones can name the price.

paragraphs.original: I wonder at it.
paragraphs.translated: I can't believe it.

paragraphs.original:
That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that the
fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.
paragraphs.translated: That only proves how inexperienced you are. You know that the style of a man's jacket or hat or coat means nothing.

paragraphs.original: Yes, it is apparel.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, it's just clothing.

paragraphs.original: I mean the fashion.
paragraphs.translated: No, I mean, the fashion of a man's clothing tells us nothing about the man.

paragraphs.original: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, fashion is fashion.

paragraphs.original:
Tush, I may as well say the fool's the fool. But seest thou not
what a deformed thief this fashion is?
paragraphs.translated:
C'mon, I might as well say the fool's the fool! But don't you see what a
deformed villain fashion is?
deformed

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I know that Deformed. He has been a vile thief this
(aside)
seven year. He goes up and down like a gentleman. I
remember his name.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only the other WATCHMEN can hear) I know that man,
Deformed. For the past seven years, he's been a wicked thief. He walks around as if he were a gentleman. I remember that name.
(speaking so that only the other
can hear)
Deformed

paragraphs.original: Didst thou not hear somebody?
paragraphs.translated: Did you hear someone?

paragraphs.original: No, 'twas the vane on the house.
paragraphs.translated: Just the weathervane moving.

paragraphs.original:
Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is,
how giddily he turns about all the hot bloods between
fourteen and five-and-thirty, sometimes fashioning them
like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy painting, sometime
like god Bel's priests in the old church-window, sometime
like the shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten
tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?
paragraphs.translated:
As I was saying, fashion is a deformed villain. It makes hot-blooded young men spin around feverishly, forever changing their appearances, dictating that sometimes they dress like Pharoah's soldiers in that grimy painting and sometimes like the priests of the god Baal, as seen in old church windows. And sometimes fashion dresses them like the great Hercules in that dirty, worm-eaten tapestry - the one where his
codpiece seems almost as big as his club.
codpiece

paragraphs.original:
All this I see, and I see that the fashion wears out more
apparel than the man. But art not thou thyself giddy with
the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into
telling me of the fashion?
paragraphs.translated: I get all this. And I also understand how fashion changes so quickly that a man's clothing never gets a chance to wear itself out. But you're all wound up about fashion, too. Otherwise, why would you stray from your story to blabber on about it?

paragraphs.original:
Not so, neither. But know that I have tonight wooed
Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the name of
Hero. She leans me out at her mistress' chamber window,
bids me a thousand times good night. I tell this tale vilely.
I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio and my
master, planted and placed and possessed by my master
Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable
encounter.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'm not wound up. But I will tell you that I seduced Margaret, the Lady Hero's waiting woman, tonight. I called her "Hero" the whole time. She leaned out of her mistress's bedroom window and told me good night a thousand times - but I am telling this story poorly. I should backtrack and begin with how my master, Don John, arranged for the Prince, Claudio, and himself to witness this friendly encounter from the orchard.

paragraphs.original: And thought they Margaret was Hero?
paragraphs.translated: And they thought Margaret was Hero?

paragraphs.original:
Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the devil my
master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths,
which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which
did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did
confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went
Claudio enraged, swore he would meet her as he was
appointed next morning at the temple, and there, before the
whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o'ernight
and send her home again without a husband.
paragraphs.translated: The Prince and Claudio did, but the devil, my master, knew that it was Margaret. They believed the charade partially because of my master's testimony - which first caused them to doubt Hero - and partially because of how dark and deceiving the night was, but mostly because of my villainous actions, which confirmed Don John's slander. Claudio went away enraged, swearing that he'd meet Hero at the temple as planned and there, before the entire congregation, shame her with what he'd discovered and send her home without a husband.

paragraphs.original: We charge you, in the Prince's name, stand!
paragraphs.translated: We charge you, in the Prince's name, to stop!

paragraphs.original:
Call up the right Master Constable. We have here
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was
known in the commonwealth.
paragraphs.translated:
Call up the Master Constable Dogberry. We have
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that was ever known in the commonwealth.
recovered

paragraphs.original:
And one Deformed is one of them. I know him; he wears a
lock.
paragraphs.translated: And one of them is the criminal Deformed. I know him; he wears a lock of hair.

paragraphs.original: Masters, masters -
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, gentlemen -

paragraphs.original:
(to BORACHIO) You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I
(to
)
warrant you.

Masters, never speak, we charge you, let us obey you go
with us.
paragraphs.translated:
Gentlemen, don't speak. We
obey you to go with us.
obey

paragraphs.original:
We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of
these men's bills.
paragraphs.translated: We're probably a very valuable catch for these guys.

paragraphs.original:
A commodity in question, I warrant you. - Come, we'll
obey you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, our value is debatable, I bet. Let's go, we'll obey you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter HERO,MARGARET, and URSULA
paragraphs.translated: HERO, MARGARET, andURSULA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to
rise.
paragraphs.translated: Good Ursula, go wake my cousin and ask her to get up.

paragraphs.original: I will, lady.
paragraphs.translated: I will, lady.

paragraphs.original: And bid her come hither.
paragraphs.translated: And request that she come here.

paragraphs.original: Well.
paragraphs.translated: Very well.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: Troth, I think your other rebato were better.
paragraphs.translated: Really, I think your other ruff is better.

paragraphs.original: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.
paragraphs.translated: No, please good Meg, I'll wear this one.

paragraphs.original:
By my troth, 's not so good, and I warrant your cousin will
say so.
paragraphs.translated: Honestly, it's not as good as the other one, and I'm sure your cousin will agree with me.

paragraphs.original:
My cousin's a fool, and thou art another. I'll wear none but
this.
paragraphs.translated: My cousin's a fool, and you are too. I'll wear this one and none other.

paragraphs.original:
I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a
thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i'
faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so.
paragraphs.translated: I like your new wig and headdress, though I'd like it more if the hair were a shade browner. And your gown is really stylish. You know, I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown, the one that everyone praises so highly.

paragraphs.original: Oh, that exceeds, they say.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, they say that dress surpasses all others.

paragraphs.original:
By my troth, 's but a nightgown in respect of yours - cloth
o' gold, and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls,
down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne
with a bluish tinsel. But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and
excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.
paragraphs.translated: Compared to your dress, it's no better than a nightgown. The cloth is interwoven with gold thread, and slashes in the material show the fabric beneath. It is trimmed with silver lace and embroidered with pearls. It has one set of fitted sleeves and another ornamental pair that hangs open from the shoulders. The skirts are trimmed with a blue, metallic fabric. But for a fine, elegant, graceful, and excellent dress, yours is worth ten of those.

paragraphs.original: God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.
paragraphs.translated: I hope I enjoy wearing it, for my heart is very heavy.

paragraphs.original: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.
paragraphs.translated: It will be made even heavier soon - by the weight of a man.

paragraphs.original: Fie upon thee! Art not ashamed?
paragraphs.translated: Watch your tongue! Have you no shame?

paragraphs.original:
Of what, lady? Of speaking honorably? Is not marriage
honorable in a beggar? Is not your lord honorable without
marriage? I think you would have me say, "Saving your
reverence, a husband." An bad thinking do not wrest true
speaking, I'll offend nobody. Is there any harm in "the
heavier for a husband"? None, I think, an it be the right
husband and the right wife. Otherwise, 'tis light and not
heavy. Ask my Lady Beatrice else. Here she comes.
