paragraphs.translated:
Shame of what, lady? Sex and marriage are honorable things - even for a beggar, right? And isn't your husband an honorable man? You're so prudish you'd probably like me to say, "I beg your pardon, your husband" - as if husband were a dirty word! So long as suspicious minds aren't misinterpreting my honest words, I'll offend no one. What's wrong with admitting your husband's going to lie on you? Nothing, as long as it's the right husband with the right wife. That's right and proper - anything else is frivolous and immoral. Ask Beatrice. Here she comes.
husband

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, coz.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, cousin.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, sweet Hero.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, sweet Hero.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune?
paragraphs.translated: Why do you sound so odd? Are you ill? You sound out of tune.

paragraphs.original: I am out of all other tune, methinks.
paragraphs.translated: I must be ill - I don't think I can speak in any other tune.

paragraphs.original:
Clap 's into "Light o' love." That goes without a burden.
Do you sing it, and I'll dance it.
paragraphs.translated: If it's a tune we want, let's sing "Light on Love!" It's a light song and doesn't require a man to sing the baritone. You sing, and I'll dance.

paragraphs.original:
Ye light o' love, with your heels! Then, if your husband
have stables enough, you'll see he shall lack no barns.
paragraphs.translated: You're "light on love" sure enough - your frivolous dancing proves you have light heels! When you're married one of these days, if your husband is rolling in dough, you'll let him roll in the hay whenever he wants.

paragraphs.original: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.
paragraphs.translated:
Never! I reject that life; I kick it away with my
heels.
heels

paragraphs.original:
'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin. 'Tis time you were ready.
By my troth, I am exceeding ill. Heigh-ho!
For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?
paragraphs.translated: Are you sighing for a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

paragraphs.original: For the letter that begins them all, H.
paragraphs.translated: I have an ache; I'm sighing for the letter that begins all those words.

paragraphs.original:
Well, an you be not turned Turk, there's no more sailing by
the star.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, if you haven't
renounced your old faith yet, we can't trust anything anymore.
renounced

paragraphs.original: What means the fool, trow?
paragraphs.translated: What does the fool mean by that, I wonder?

paragraphs.original: Nothing, I; but God send everyone their heart's desire.
paragraphs.translated: I don't mean anything - but God sends everyone their heart's desire.

paragraphs.original:
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent
perfume.
paragraphs.translated: The Count sent me an excellent pair of perfumed gloves.

paragraphs.original: I am stuffed, cousin. I cannot smell.
paragraphs.translated: Sorry, I'm all stuffed. I can't smell a thing.

paragraphs.original: A maid, and stuffed! There's goodly catching of cold.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, just a young lady and already
stuffed! That's a nice way to catch a cold.
stuffed!

paragraphs.original:
Oh, God help me, God help me! How long have you
professed apprehension?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, God help me! Since when have you claimed to be such a great wit?

paragraphs.original: Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?
paragraphs.translated: Ever since you lost yours. Doesn't my wit suit me well?

paragraphs.original:
It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap. By my
troth, I am sick.
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't get seen enough; you should wear it in your cap, the way fools wear coxcombs. God, I'm really sick.

paragraphs.original:
Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus and lay it
to your heart. It is the only thing for a qualm.
paragraphs.translated:
You should get some distilled
carduus benedictus and put it on your chest. It's the only way to cure a sudden faintness.
carduus benedictus

paragraphs.original: There thou prick'st her with a thistle.
paragraphs.translated: With that you've managed to prick her with a thistle.

paragraphs.original:
Benedictus! Why benedictus? You have some moral in this
benedictus?
benedictus?
paragraphs.translated:
Benedictus! Why do you suggest I use benedictus? Is there some double meaning in that word, "benedictus"?
Benedictus
benedictus

paragraphs.original:
Moral! No, by my troth, I have no moral meaning. I meant
plain holy thistle. You may think perchance that I think you
are in love. Nay, by 'r Lady, I am not such a fool to think
what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I
cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that
you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be
in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he
become a man. He swore he would never marry, and yet
now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without
grudging. And how you may be converted I know not, but
methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.
paragraphs.translated: Double meaning! No, honestly, there's no other meaning. I just meant that you should use some holy thistle. Maybe you think that I think you're in love. No, by Our Lady, I'm not such a fool to think what I please, and I don't please to think what I can, and in fact I cannot think, even if I could think my heart right past thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or even that you can be in love. But Benedick was once an enemy of love as well, and now he's become a real man. He swore that he'd never get married, but now, despite his earlier protestations, he loves ungrudgingly. How we're going to convert you I'll never know. And yet I think you look with your eyes just like every other woman does.

paragraphs.original: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you talking at such a crazy clip?

paragraphs.original: Not a false gallop.
paragraphs.translated: It's not a false gallop, anyway.

paragraphs.original: Enter URSULA
paragraphs.translated: URSULA enters.

paragraphs.original:
Madam, withdraw: the Prince, the Count, Signor
Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are
come to fetch you to church.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, we have to go: the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gentlemen of the town have come to bring you to church.

paragraphs.original: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
paragraphs.translated: Good cousin, good Meg, good Ursula, come help me get dressed.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO withDOGBERRY and VERGES
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO enters withDOGBERRY andVERGES.

paragraphs.original: What would you with me, honest neighbor?
paragraphs.translated: What do you want from me, my good man?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that
decerns you nearly.
paragraphs.translated:
Please, sir, I would like to discuss some news that
decerns you greatly.
decerns

paragraphs.original: Brief, I pray you, for you see it is a busy time with me.
paragraphs.translated: Be brief, please, because, as you can see, this is a busy time for me.

paragraphs.original: Marry, this it is, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, sir, it is.

paragraphs.original: Yes, in truth it is, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, it truly is.

paragraphs.original: What is it, my good friends?
paragraphs.translated: What's the news, my good friends?

paragraphs.original:
Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter. An old
man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would
desire they were, but, in faith, honest as the skin between
his brows.
paragraphs.translated:
Sorry, sir, Goodman Verges tends to ramble. He's an old man, sir, and his wits are not as
blunt as I wish they were. But truly, he's as honest as the skin between his brows.
blunt

paragraphs.original:
Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an
old man and no honester than I.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I thank God that I am as honest as all the other old men who are not honester than me.

paragraphs.original:
Comparisons are odorous. Palabras, neighbor Verges.
Palabras
paragraphs.translated:
Making comparisons is
odorous, Verges. Get on with your story.
odorous

paragraphs.original: Neighbors, you are tedious.
paragraphs.translated: Friends, you are becoming tedious.

paragraphs.original:
It pleases your Worship to say so, but we are the poor duke's
officers. But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as
a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your
worship.
paragraphs.translated:
Thank you for saying that, your Worship, but we're just the poor duke's officers. But truly, if I were as
tedious as a king, I would give everything to you, your Worship.
tedious

paragraphs.original: All thy tediousness on me, ah?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, so you'd give me all your tediousness?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis, for I hear
as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the
city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, even if I had a thousand more pounds than that, for I hear that you are
exclaimed throughout the city, and though I am only a poor man, it makes me glad to hear it.
exclaimed

paragraphs.original: And so am I.
paragraphs.translated: Me, too.

paragraphs.original: I would fain know what you have to say.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, please, I'd like to hear your news.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your Worship's
presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in
Messina.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, our watch tonight - 
expectfully, sir - has captured a couple of the worst criminals in Messina.
expectfully

paragraphs.original:
A good old man, sir. He will be talking. As they say, "When
the age is in, the wit is out." God help us, it is a world to see!
Well said, i' faith, neighbor Verges. - Well, God's a good
man. An two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An
honest soul, i' faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke
bread, but God is to be worshipped, all men are not alike,
alas, good neighbor!
Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short of you.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, my friend, he isn't nearly as impressive as you are.

paragraphs.original: Gifts that God gives.
paragraphs.translated: God gives those gifts - I had nothing to do with it.

paragraphs.original: I must leave you.
paragraphs.translated: Now I must return to the wedding.

paragraphs.original:
One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended
two aspicious persons, and we would have them this
morning examined before your worship.
paragraphs.translated:
One more thing, sir. Our watch, sir, as you know, has
comprehended two auspicious persons. We'd like for you to examine them this morning.
comprehended

paragraphs.original:
Take their examination yourself and bring it me. I am now
in great haste, as it may appear unto you.
paragraphs.translated: Examine them yourselves, then bring me your findings. Now I'm in a great hurry, as I'm sure you can see.

paragraphs.original: It shall be suffigance.
paragraphs.translated:
That will be
suffigance.
suffigance

paragraphs.original: Drink some wine ere you go. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: Have some wine before you go. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her
husband.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, they're waiting for you to give your daughter away to Claudio.

paragraphs.original: I'll wait upon them. I am ready.
paragraphs.translated: I'm coming.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEONATO andMESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and theMESSENGER exit.

paragraphs.original:
Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole. Bid him
bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail. We are now to
examination these men.
paragraphs.translated:
Go to Francis Seacole, the constable of the watch. Tell him to bring his pen and his inkwell to the jail. We will now go to
examination these men.
examination

paragraphs.original: And we must do it wisely.
paragraphs.translated: We must do this wisely.

paragraphs.original:
We will spare for no wit, I warrant you. Here's that shall
drive some of them to a noncome. Only get the learned
writer to set down our excommunication and meet me at
the jail.
paragraphs.translated:
We won't hold back any of our wisdom. We'll drive them to a
noncome. Go get the educated writer to record our excommunication, and I'll meet you at the jail.
noncome

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,HERO, BEATRICE, and Attendants
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, DON JOHN,LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS,CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,HERO, and BEATRICE enter withATTENDANTS.

paragraphs.original:
Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the plain form of
marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties
afterwards.
paragraphs.translated: All right, Friar Francis, let's keep this short. Do a simple ceremony, and list all the particular duties of marriage later.

paragraphs.original: No.
paragraphs.translated: No.

paragraphs.original: To be married to her. - Friar, you come to marry her.
paragraphs.translated:
No, he comes to be married to her. Friar, you are the one who has come to marry her.
to

paragraphs.original: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count?
paragraphs.translated: Lady, do you come here to be married to this count?

paragraphs.original: I do.
paragraphs.translated: I do.

paragraphs.original:
If either of you know any inward impediment why you
should not be conjoined, charge you on your souls to utter
it.
paragraphs.translated: If either of you knows any secret reason why you two should not be joined in marriage, I order you on your souls to say so.

paragraphs.original: Know you any, Hero?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know any, Hero?

paragraphs.original: None, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: None, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Know you any, count?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know any, count?

paragraphs.original: I dare make his answer, none.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sure I can answer for him - he doesn't know any, either.

paragraphs.original:
O, what men dare do! What men may do! What men daily
do, not knowing what they do!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, the things men dare to do! The things men are allowed to do! The things men do daily, not knowing what they're doing!

paragraphs.original:
How now, interjections? Why, then, some be of laughing,
as, ah, ha, he!
paragraphs.translated:
What, are we playing with interjections? Well then, add some interjections that indicate laughter, like
"ah," "ha," and "he!"
"ah," "ha," and "he!"

paragraphs.original:
Stand thee by, Friar. - Father, by your leave,
Will you with free and unconstrainèd soul
Give me this maid, your daughter?
As freely, son, as God did give her me.
paragraphs.translated: As freely, son, as God gave her to me.

paragraphs.original:
And what have I to give you back whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
paragraphs.translated: And what should I give you that would be equal in value to this rare and precious gift?

paragraphs.original: Nothing, unless you render her again.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing, sir, except grandchildren.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness. - 
There, Leonato, take her back again.
Give not this rotten orange to your friend.
She's but the sign and semblance of her honor.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
Oh, what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,
All you that see her, that she were a maid
By these exterior shows? But she is none.
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
paragraphs.translated: Good Prince, you have taught me how to accept things nobly. There, Leonato, take your daughter back. Don't insult a friend by giving him a beautiful orange that rots inside. She only appears honorable from the outside. Look, how she blushes like a virgin! Oh, sin can disguise itself so artfully! Doesn't that rising blush suggest that she is virtuous and innocent? All of you who are looking at her, wouldn't you swear that she's a virgin, judging by these outward shows? But she is no virgin. She has been in a man's bed. She blushes from guilt, not modesty.

paragraphs.original: What do you mean, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approvèd wanton.
paragraphs.translated: I won't be married. I won't join my soul to such a proven slut.

paragraphs.original:
Dear my lord, if you in your own proof
Have vanquished the resistance of her youth
And made defeat of her virginity -
paragraphs.translated: My dear lord, if it was you who conquered her and took her virginity -

paragraphs.original:
I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the forehand sin.
No, Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large
But, as a brother to his sister, showed
Bashful sincerity and comely love.
paragraphs.translated: I know what you're about to say. If I had slept with her, you'd say that we did so as husband and wife, merely anticipating our eventual marriage. No, Leonato. I never seduced her, or tempted her with indecent words. I treated her like a brother would treat a sister, with modest sincerity and appropriate affection.

paragraphs.original: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?
paragraphs.translated: And have I ever seemed less than modest or appropriate to you?

paragraphs.original:
Out on thee, seeming! I will write against it.
You seem to me as Dian in her orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown.
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus, or those pampered animals
That rage in savage sensuality.
paragraphs.translated:
Curse you for your false appearances! To me, you seemed like
Diana in her orbit - as virginal as the flower bud before it blooms. But you're actually as hot-blooded as Venus, or a pampered animal allowed to run wild.
Diana

paragraphs.original: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?
paragraphs.translated: Are you sick, my lord? Is that why you're talking so wildly?

paragraphs.original: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?
paragraphs.translated: Good Prince, say something!

paragraphs.original:
What should I speak?
I stand dishonored, that have gone about
To link my dear friend to a common stale.
paragraphs.translated: What should I say? I've been dishonored: I arranged for a friend of mine to marry a common whore.

paragraphs.original: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?
paragraphs.translated: Are you really saying these things, or am I dreaming?

paragraphs.original: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.
paragraphs.translated: They're really being spoken, sir, and they're true.

paragraphs.original: This looks not like a nuptial.
paragraphs.translated: This doesn't look like a wedding.

paragraphs.original: True! O God!
paragraphs.translated: It's true! Oh God!

paragraphs.original:
Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince's brother?
Is this face Hero's? Are our eyes our own?
paragraphs.translated: Leonato, am I standing here? Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince's brother? Is this face Hero's? Are these our eyes?

paragraphs.original: All this is so, but what of this, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's all true - but what do you mean by it, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Let me but move one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.
paragraphs.translated: Let me just ask her one question, and by your authority as her father, order her to answer truthfully.

paragraphs.original: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.
paragraphs.translated: As my child, I order you to do so.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, God defend me! how am I beset! - 
What kind of catechizing call you this?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, God help me! How I'm being attacked! What kind of game is this?

paragraphs.original: To make you answer truly to your name.
paragraphs.translated: We just want you to answer to your real name.

paragraphs.original:
Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't my name Hero? Who can stain that name with a just accusation?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, that can Hero!
Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue.
What man was he talked with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, Hero herself can! You've stained your virtue with your own actions. What man were you talking to at your window last night, between the hours of midnight and one? If you're a virgin, you'll answer this question.

paragraphs.original: I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I wasn't talking to any man at that time, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
Why, then are you no maiden. - Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear. Upon mine honor,
Myself, my brother, and this grievèd count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window
Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,
Confessed the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.
paragraphs.translated:
Well then, you are no virgin. Leonato, I'm sorry you have to hear this. I swear on my honor that we saw and heard Hero talking to a brute at her window last night.
And that man confessed at length how he has secretly come to her bedroom thousands of times.

paragraphs.original:
Fie, fie, they are not to be named, my lord,
Not to be spoke of!
There is not chastity enough in language,
Without offense, to utter them. - Thus, pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord, don't name her sinful acts or speak of them! There's no way to describe them without offending everyone here. Pretty lady, I'm much ashamed of your shocking behavior.

paragraphs.original:
O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! Farewell,
Thou pure impiety and impious purity.
For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love,
And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh Hero, you could have equaled the
mythical Hero if only half your outward beauty matched your inner thoughts and desires! Goodbye, beautiful sinner. Goodbye to your pure wickedness and your wicked purity. Because of you, I'll keep myself away from love. I'll hang suspicion on my eyelids, so that all the beautiful things I see are transformed into dangers and are never able to trick me again.
mythical Hero

paragraphs.original: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me?
paragraphs.translated: Does anyone have a dagger for me?

paragraphs.original: HERO swoons
paragraphs.translated: HERO faints.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?
paragraphs.translated: What's wrong, cousin? Why have you collapsed?

paragraphs.original:
Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up.
paragraphs.translated: Come, let's go. These revelations have overwhelmed her.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO exit.

paragraphs.original: How doth the lady?
paragraphs.translated: How is she?

paragraphs.original:
Dead, I think. - Help, uncle! - 
Hero, why, Hero! Uncle! Signor Benedick! Friar!
paragraphs.translated: She's dead, I think. - Help, uncle! - Hero, why Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

paragraphs.original:
O Fate! Take not away thy heavy hand!
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wished for.
paragraphs.translated: Oh Fate, don't spare Hero from being punished! Death is the best way to cover over her shame.

paragraphs.original: How now, cousin Hero!
paragraphs.translated: How are you, Hero?

paragraphs.original: HERO stirs
paragraphs.translated: HERO stirs.

paragraphs.original: Yea, wherefore should she not?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, why shouldn't she?

paragraphs.original:
Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood? - 
Do not live, Hero, do not ope thine eyes,
For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,
Strike at thy life. Grieved I I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal Nature's frame?
O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar's issue at my gates,
Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy,
I might have said, "No part of it is mine;
This shame derives itself from unknown loins"?
paragraphs.translated:
Why not! Isn't every living thing condemning her? Can she deny the accusations that are proven by her guilty blush? Die, Hero, don't open your eyes. If I didn't think you were about to die soon - if I thought your spirit could bear this shame - I would risk punishment and kill you myself. Am I sorry that I only had one child? Do I blame Nature for being so thrifty? Oh, one child is one too many! Why did I ever have one? Why did you once seem lovely to me? Why didn't I just adopt a beggar's child left at my doorstep, whose shame and dishonor I could have denied, not being its true father?
But you were mine, and I loved and praised you for being mine, and was proud of you for being mine - I loved you so much that I hardly cared about myself.

paragraphs.original:
But mine, and mine I loved, and mine I praised,
And mine that I was proud on, mine so much
That I myself was to myself not mine,
Valuing of her - why, she, O she is fall'n
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, but now you have fallen into a pit of ink, and there's not enough water in the whole wide sea to wash you clean again, and not enough salt to cover your stink.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, sir, be patient.
For my part, I am so attired in wonder
I know not what to say.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, sir, calm down. I'm so amazed by this, I don't know what to say.

paragraphs.original: Oh, on my soul, my cousin is belied!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, on my soul, my cousin has been slandered falsely!

paragraphs.original: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?
paragraphs.translated: Lady, did you sleep in her room last night?

paragraphs.original:
No, truly not, although until last night
I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.
paragraphs.translated: No, I didn't, but I did every night for the past year.

paragraphs.original:
Confirmed, confirmed! Oh, that is stronger made
Which was before barred up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so that, speaking of her foulness,
Washed it with tears? Hence from her. Let her die.
paragraphs.translated: Then it's confirmed! That's even more proof, and the case against her was airtight already. Would the two princes and Claudio lie? Claudio, who loved her so much that talking about her wickedness made him weep?

paragraphs.original:
Hear me a little,
For I have only silent been so long,
And given way unto this course of fortune,
By noting of the lady. I have marked
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes,
And in her eye there hath appeared a fire
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool,
paragraphs.translated:
Listen to me a moment. I've only remained silent this whole time because I've been watching Hero. I've seen her begin to blush a thousand times, only to watch those blushes disappear a thousand times and an innocent paleness take over her face. And in her eyes I see a fire that would seem to burn away the lies the princes have told about her chastity. Call me a fool,

don't trust my observations - the truth of which is backed up by all my years of experience - don't trust my age, my reputation, my position, and my holiness.

paragraphs.original:
Trust not my reading nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenor of my book; trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
Under some biting error.
paragraphs.translated: You can doubt all these things if this sweet lady turns out to be guilty.

paragraphs.original:
Friar, it cannot be.
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury. She not denies it.
Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?
paragraphs.translated: But she must be, Friar. You see that any morals she has left are preventing her from denying the charges: she doesn't want to add perjury to her list of sins.

paragraphs.original: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?
paragraphs.translated: Lady, who do they accuse you of having taken as your lover?

paragraphs.original:
They know that do accuse me. I know none.
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy! - O my father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintained the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!
paragraphs.translated: You should ask them. I don't know who they're talking about. If I've been with a man in any improper way, let all my sins be punished! Oh, father, if you yourself can prove that I talked with a man at an indecent hour, or indeed that I spoke to any creature last night, you can disown me, hate me, and torture me to death!

paragraphs.original: There is some strange misprision in the princes.
paragraphs.translated: The princes are under some strange misunderstanding.

paragraphs.original:
Two of them have the very bent of honor,
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practice of it lives in John the Bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.
paragraphs.translated: Two of them are completely honorable, and if they have been tricked in this, we must blame John the Bastard, who lives to create conflict.

paragraphs.original:
I know not. If they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine
Nor age so eat up my invention
Nor fortune made such havoc of my means
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends
But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb and policy of mind,
Ability in means and choice of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.
paragraphs.translated:
I don't know. If they have spoken the truth about Hero, I will tear her apart with my bare hands. But if they have accused her falsely, even the greatest of them will have to deal with me. Age hasn't dried up my body or eroded my intelligence so much, and luck hasn't robbed me of so much of my fortune, and my bad ways
haven't deprived me of so many friends, that they won't find me ready to seek revenge both physically and mentally, with money and friends at my disposal.

paragraphs.original:
Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Your daughter here the princes left for dead.
Let her awhile be secretly kept in
And publish it that she is dead indeed.
Maintain a mourning ostentation,
And on your family's old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.
paragraphs.translated: Hold on a moment, and listen to my advice. The princes left your daughter here for dead. Hide her for a while in your house, and tell everyone that she has, in fact, died. Make a bug show of mourning for her, hang sad epitaphs up at your family's tomb, and perform all the appropriate burial ceremonies.

paragraphs.original: What shall become of this? What will this do?
paragraphs.translated: Why should we do this? What will this do?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, this, well carried, shall on her behalf
Change slander to remorse. That is some good.
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth.
She, dying, as it must so be maintained,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied and excused
Of every hearer. For it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost,
Why then we rack the value, then we find
paragraphs.translated:
Listen, if we do this correctly, the men who slandered Hero will feel remorse for her instead. That will be a good thing. But I have an even greater goal in mind. We'll maintain that she died the instant she was accused, and everyone who hears this will grieve for her, pity her, and excuse her actions. That's how it goes: we don't value the things we have until we lose them, when we suddenly rack up their value and see

all the virtues we were blind to when they were alive and with us. That's how Claudio will respond. When he hears that she died from his words, his imagination will be sweetly overtaken by thoughts of her. In death, every aspect of her life will be got up more beautifully, and in his mind she will seem more moving, more delicate, and more lively even than when she was alive. Then, if he ever truly felt love, he'll mourn and wish he hadn't accused her - even though he believed his accu-

paragraphs.original:
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio.
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
The idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely organ of her life
Shall come apparelled in more precious habit,
More moving, delicate and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul
Than when she lived indeed. Then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her,
No, though he thought his accusation true.
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be leveled false,
The supposition of the lady's death
Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.
paragraphs.translated: sation to be true. Follow my plan, and trust that the actual events will play out even better than I am describing. And even if they don't, at least Hero's supposed death will stop the rumors of her infidelity. And if it doesn't go well, then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery, the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation - away from the public's eyes, tongues, mind, and insults.

paragraphs.original:
Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you.
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.
paragraphs.translated: Signior Leonato, listen to the friar's plan. And even though you know I'm very close to the Prince and Claudio, I swear I'll keep your counsel and deal with this secretly and justly.

paragraphs.original:
Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.
paragraphs.translated: Because I'm drowning in my grief, I'll grab onto the smallest piece of string dangled in front of me.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis well consented. Presently away,
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure. - 
Come, lady, die to live. This wedding day
Perhaps is but prolonged. Have patience and endure.
paragraphs.translated: This is a good agreement. Now, let's go. A strange disease requires a strange cure. Come, lady; you must die in order to live. Hopefully, your wedding day is only postponed. Have patience and endure.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but BENEDICK andBEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but BENEDICK andBEATRICE exits.

paragraphs.original: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?
paragraphs.translated: Lady Beatrice, have you been crying this entire time?

paragraphs.original: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and I'll keep crying a while longer.

paragraphs.original: I will not desire that.
paragraphs.translated: I don't wish that on you.

paragraphs.original: You have no reason. I do it freely.
paragraphs.translated: You don't have to; I do it of my own free will.

paragraphs.original: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.
paragraphs.translated: I really believe your cousin was falsely accused.

paragraphs.original:
Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would
right her!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, the man who avenged her could ask anything of me!

paragraphs.original: Is there any way to show such friendship?
paragraphs.translated: Is there any way I could show such friendship to you?

paragraphs.original: A very even way, but no such friend.
paragraphs.translated: A very clear way, but there is no friend who will undertake it.

paragraphs.original: May a man do it?
paragraphs.translated: Can a man do it?

paragraphs.original: It is a man's office, but not yours.
paragraphs.translated: It's a job meant for a man, but not you.

paragraphs.original:
I do love nothing in the world so well as you. Is not that
strange?
paragraphs.translated: There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you. Isn't that strange?

paragraphs.original:
As strange as the thing I know not. It were as possible for
me to say I loved nothing so well as you, but believe me not,
and yet I lie not, I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am
sorry for my cousin.
paragraphs.translated: It's as strange as this other thing which I don't understand. I could just as easily say that there is nothing in the world that I love as much as you. But don't believe me - though I'm not lying. I confess nothing, and I deny nothing. I feel awful for my cousin.

paragraphs.original: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.
paragraphs.translated: By my sword, Beatrice, you love me.

paragraphs.original: Do not swear, and eat it.
paragraphs.translated:
Don't swear like that and then go back and
eat it later.
eat it

paragraphs.original:
I will swear by it that you love me, and I will make him eat
it that says I love not you.
paragraphs.translated:
I'll swear by my
sword that you love me, too, and I'll make any man who says that I don't love you eat it.
sword

paragraphs.original: Will you not eat your word?
paragraphs.translated: But you won't eat your words?

paragraphs.original: With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I love thee.
paragraphs.translated: Not with any sauce they could provide for them. I swear, I love you.

paragraphs.original: Why then, God forgive me.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, God forgive me!

paragraphs.original: What offense, sweet Beatrice?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what have you done, sweet Beatrice?

paragraphs.original:
You have stayed me in a happy hour. I was about to protest
I loved you.
paragraphs.translated: You got to me first. I was about to swear that I loved you.

paragraphs.original: And do it with all thy heart.
paragraphs.translated: Then do so, with all your heart.

paragraphs.original:
I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to
protest.
paragraphs.translated: I love you with so much of my heart that none of it is left to protest with.

paragraphs.original: Come, bid me do anything for thee.
paragraphs.translated: Come, ask me to do anything for you.

paragraphs.original: Kill Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: Kill Claudio.

paragraphs.original: Ha! Not for the wide world.
paragraphs.translated: Ha! I wouldn't do that for the whole wide world.

paragraphs.original: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
Then, rejecting my request, you kill me, instead. Goodbye.
me,

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE begins to exit
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE begins to exit.

paragraphs.original: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated: Wait, sweet Beatrice.

paragraphs.original:
I am gone, though I am here. There is no love in you. Nay,
I pray you let me go.
paragraphs.translated: My body waits here, but the rest of me is gone. You don't really love me. I beg you to let me go.

paragraphs.original: Beatrice -
paragraphs.translated: Beatrice -

paragraphs.original: In faith, I will go.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, I'm going.

paragraphs.original: We'll be friends first.
paragraphs.translated: Not until we part as friends.

paragraphs.original:
You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine
enemy.
paragraphs.translated: How dare you try to be my friend when you refuse to fight my enemy.

paragraphs.original: Is Claudio thine enemy?
paragraphs.translated: Is Claudio your enemy?

paragraphs.original:
Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath
slandered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman? Oh, that I
were a man! What, bear her in hand until they come to take
hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered
slander, unmitigated rancor - O God, that I were a man! I
would eat his heart in the marketplace.
paragraphs.translated: Hasn't he proven himself to be a great villain - slandering, scorning, and dishonoring my cousin? Oh, I wish I were a man! He pretended that everything was fine until the moment they were exchanging vows, and then - with public accusation, blatant slander, pure hatred - Oh God, if only I were a man! I would rip his heart out in public and eat it.

paragraphs.original: Hear me, Beatrice -
paragraphs.translated: Listen to me, Beatrice -

paragraphs.original: Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!
paragraphs.translated: Talking with a man outside her bedroom window! A likely story!

paragraphs.original: Nay, but Beatrice -
paragraphs.translated: No, but Beatrice -

paragraphs.original:
Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is
undone.
paragraphs.translated: Sweet Hero, she's been wronged, she's been slandered, she's been ruined.

paragraphs.original: Beat -
paragraphs.translated: Beat -

paragraphs.original:
Princes and counties! Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly
count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely! Oh, that I
were a man for his sake! Or that I had any friend would be
a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into curtsies,
valor into compliment, and men are only turned into
tongue, and trim ones too. He is now as valiant as Hercules
that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a man with
wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.
paragraphs.translated: Princes and counts! Oh, of course, it was all so proper and ceremonious - they gave a truly princely testimony. He's a proper count, that Count Sugarplum, a sweet gentleman, for sure! Oh, if only I were a man! Or had a friend who would be a man for me! But there are no real men left. Their manliness has melted into pretty curtsies and fancy manners, and their bravery is spent on making clever compliments. All this conversing has turned men into tongues - and fancy ones, at that. The man who tells a lie and swears by it is now considered as brave as Hercules. I can't make myself a man by wishing I were, so as a woman I'll die, from grieving.

paragraphs.original: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.
paragraphs.translated: Wait, good Beatrice. I swear by this hand that I love you.

paragraphs.original: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.
paragraphs.translated: Don't just swear by it; put your hand to some use that will prove you love me.

paragraphs.original:
Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged
Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
Do you honestly think, in your soul, that Claudio has wrongly accused
Hero?
Hero?

paragraphs.original: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

paragraphs.original:
Enough, I am engaged. I will challenge him. I will kiss your
hand, and so I leave you. By this hand, Claudio shall render
me a dear account. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go
comfort your cousin. I must say she is dead, and so,
farewell.
paragraphs.translated: That's enough for me, then. I'll challenge him. I'll kiss your hand, and with that I leave you. I swear that Claudio will pay dearly for this. Keep me in your thoughts and go comfort your cousin. I'll go tell them that she's dead. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DOGBERRY,VERGES, andSEXTON, in gowns; and the Watch, withCONRADE and BORACHIO
DOGBERRY,VERGES
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY, VERGES, the SEXTON (in his official gown), and theWATCHMEN enter, bringing CONRADE and BORACHIO.

paragraphs.original: Is our whole dissembly appeared?
paragraphs.translated:
Is our whole
dissembly here?
dissembly

paragraphs.original: Oh, a stool and a cushion for the Sexton.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, we need a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

paragraphs.original: A stool is brought in. SEXTON sits
paragraphs.translated: A stool is brought in. The SEXTON sits down.

paragraphs.original: Which be the malefactors?
paragraphs.translated: Which ones are the malefactors?

paragraphs.original: Marry, that am I and my partner.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, that would be me and my partner.

paragraphs.original: Nay, that's certain; we have the exhibition to examine.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, yes, we've been
exhibitioned to examine this case.
exhibitioned

paragraphs.original:
But which are the offenders that are to be examined? Let
them come before Master Constable.
paragraphs.translated: No, you've misunderstood me - where are the criminals whom I'm supposed to examine? Have them come in front of the master constable.

paragraphs.original:
Yea, marry, let them come before me.
What is your name, friend?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, indeed, bring them before me.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO andCONRADE come forward
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO and CONRADE come forward.

paragraphs.original: What's your name, friend?
paragraphs.translated: What's your name, friend?

paragraphs.original: Borachio.
paragraphs.translated: Borachio.

paragraphs.original: Pray, write down, "Borachio." - Yours, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated: Please, write down "Borachio." - And yours?

paragraphs.original: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.
paragraphs.translated: I'm a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

paragraphs.original:
Write down "Master Gentleman Conrade." - Masters, do
you serve God?
paragraphs.translated: Write down "Master Gentleman Conrade." - Gentlemen, are you good Christians, and do you serve God?

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE, BORACHIO
Yea, sir, we hope.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE, BORACHIO
Yes, sir, we hope so.

paragraphs.original:
Write down that they hope they serve God; and write God
first, for God defend but God should go before such
villains! - Masters, it is proved already that you are little
better than false knaves, and it will go near to be thought so
shortly. How answer you for yourselves?
paragraphs.translated: Write down that they hope they serve God. Oh, and write "God" first - for God forbid we put these criminals before God! - Gentlemen, it's already been proven that you aren't much better than lying criminals, and soon we'll know almost for certain. How do you both plead?

paragraphs.original: Marry, sir, we say we are none.
paragraphs.translated: Honestly, sir, we say that we are not criminals.

paragraphs.original:
A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about
with him. - Come you hither, sirrah, a word in your ear.
Sir, I say to you it is thought you are false knaves.
paragraphs.translated: He's a marvelously witty fellow, no doubt, but I'll outmaneuver him. - Come over here; I'll whisper a word in your ear. Sir, I tell you we believe you're both lying criminals.

paragraphs.original: Sir, I say to you we are none.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I tell you that we are not.

paragraphs.original:
Well, stand aside. - 'Fore God, they are both in a ale. Have
you writ down that they are none?
paragraphs.translated: Well, okay. - I swear to God, both their stories match. Have you written that down, that they aren't criminals?

paragraphs.original:
Master Constable, you go not the way to examine. You
must call forth the watch that are their accusers.
paragraphs.translated: Master Constable, you're going about this all wrong. First, you have to speak to the watchmen who accused them.

paragraphs.original:
Yea, marry, that's the eftest way. - Let the watch come
forth. Masters, I charge you in the Prince's name, accuse
these men.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, good idea; that's the
eftest way. Bring the watchmen forward. Gentlemen, I order you in the Prince's name to accuse these men.
eftest

paragraphs.original:
This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince's brother, was
a villain.
paragraphs.translated: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince's brother, was a villain.

paragraphs.original:
Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat perjury,
to call a prince's brother villain.
paragraphs.translated:
Write down that Prince John is a villain. Why, that's flat-out
perjury - to call a prince's brother a villain.
perjury

paragraphs.original: Master Constable -
paragraphs.translated: Master Constable -

paragraphs.original:
Pray thee, fellow, peace. I do not like thy look, I promise
thee.
paragraphs.translated: Be quiet, you. I swear, I don't like the look of you.

paragraphs.original:
(to Watch) What heard you him say else?
(to Watch)
paragraphs.translated:
(to the watchmen) What else did you hear him say?
(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original:
Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John
for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.
paragraphs.translated: That Don John had given him a thousand pieces of gold for wrongfully accusing the Lady Hero.

paragraphs.original: Flat burglary as ever was committed.
paragraphs.translated: That's burglary, that is.

paragraphs.original: Yea, by Mass, that it is.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, by God, that it is.

paragraphs.original: What else, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: What else did you hear?

paragraphs.original:
And that Count Claudio did mean upon his words to
disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not marry
her.
paragraphs.translated: I heard that Count Claudio meant to disgrace Hero in front of the whole wedding party and refuse to marry her.

paragraphs.original:
(to BORACHIO) O villain! Thou wilt be condemned into
(to
)
everlasting redemption for this.
paragraphs.translated:
(to BORACHIO) Oh, you villain! You'll be condemned to everlasting
redemption for this!
(to
)
redemption

paragraphs.original: What else?
paragraphs.translated: What else?

paragraphs.original: This is all.
paragraphs.translated: That's all.

paragraphs.original:
And this is more, masters, than you can deny. Prince John
is this morning secretly stolen away. Hero was in this
manner accused, in this very manner refused, and upon the
grief of this, suddenly died. - Master Constable, let these
men be bound and brought to Leonato's. I will go before
and show him their examination.
paragraphs.translated:
(to CONRADE and BORACHIO) You can't deny this, gentlemen. This morning, Prince John secretly snuck out of Messina. Hero was accused exactly as the watchman described, and died on the spot from the grief.
(to
and
)
Master Constable, tie up these men and bring them to Leonato's. I'll get there first and tell him what we found out.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Come, let them be opinioned.
paragraphs.translated:
Come on, let's get them
opinioned.
opinioned

paragraphs.original: Let them be in the hands -
paragraphs.translated: Let them be in the hands -

paragraphs.original: Off, coxcomb!
paragraphs.translated: Get off me, you fool!

paragraphs.original:
God's my life, where's the Sexton? Let him write down the
Prince's officer "coxcomb." Come, bind them. - Thou
naughty varlet!
Away! You are an ass, you are an ass!
paragraphs.translated: Get away from me, you ass! You ass!

paragraphs.original:
Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my
years? Oh, that he were here to write me down an ass! But
masters, remember that I am an ass, though it be not
written down, yet forget not that I am an ass. - No, thou
villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by
good witness. I am a wise fellow and, which is more, an
officer and, which is more, a householder and, which is
more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in Messina, and one
that knows the law, go to, and a rich fellow enough, go to,
and a fellow that hath had losses, and one that hath two
gowns and everything handsome about him. - Bring him
away. - Oh, that I had been writ down an ass!
paragraphs.translated:
How can you call me that? Don't you suspect my office? Don't you
suspect my age? Oh, if only the sexton were here to write down that I'm an ass! Gentlemen, remember that I am an ass; even though it's not written down, don't forget that I'm an ass. Oh, you're a rotten bastard, you are. I'm a wise man and, what's more, I'm an officer of the law and, what's more, I'm a householder and, what's more, I'm as handsome a hunk of meat as any in Messina. And I know the law, damn you, and I'm rich enough, damn you, and I used to have more, but I still have two robes and lots of lovely things. - Take him away! - Oh, if only the sexton had recorded that I'm an ass!
suspect

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO andANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO enter.

paragraphs.original:
If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,
And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.
paragraphs.translated: If you keep on the way you've been going, you'll kill yourself. There's no point in adding to your grief.

paragraphs.original:
I pray thee, cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless
As water in a sieve. Give not me counsel,
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,
And bid him speak of patience.
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form.
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
Bid sorrow wag, cry "hem" when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk
With candle-wasters, bring him yet to me
And I of him will gather patience.
But there is no such man. For, brother, men
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel, but, tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion which before
Would give preceptial med'cine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air, and agony with words.
paragraphs.translated:
Stop advising me; your words pass through my ears like water through a sieve. Don't counsel me. Only someone who's been wronged as I have can comfort me. Find a father who loved his child as overwhelmingly as I loved Hero and askhim to be patient. Compare the length and width of that man's sadness against my own; match up all the complaints and strong emotions that run through our bodies. If a man who has suffered as I have gave me advice the way you do - smiling and stroking his beard, telling me to toss away my sorrow, giving speeches when he should be wailing with me, trying to heal my grief with little proverbs, spinning my head around with philosophy - then I would take his advice and be patient. But that man doesn't exist. You can try to comfort a man who feels a pain that you have never felt, but once you feel it too, your sober advice will also turn into passion. You can't treat madness with rules or bind up insanity with little silken threads or cure heartache with hot air or lighten agony with pat phrases.
him

paragraphs.original:
No, no, 'tis all men's office to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel.
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.
paragraphs.translated: Every man thinks it's his duty to advise those who are overwrought with sorrow to be patient. But no man is so moral or so strong that they can endure the same advice when they themselves are grieving. So don't advise me. My sorrow is crying too loudly to hear what you have to say.

paragraphs.original: Therein do men from children nothing differ.
paragraphs.translated: Well then you're no better than a child.

paragraphs.original:
I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood,
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently,
However they have writ the style of gods
And made a push at chance and sufferance.
paragraphs.translated: Please, leave me alone. I intend to be flesh and blood, not airy philosophy, for there has never yet been a philosopher who could endure a toothache patiently, even though they all write as if they had risen above human suffering and misfortune.

paragraphs.original:
Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself.
Make those that do offend you suffer too.
paragraphs.translated: But don't take all that pain on yourself. Make sure the ones who have wronged you suffer too.

paragraphs.original:
There thou speak'st reason. Nay, I will do so.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince
And all of them that thus dishonor her.
paragraphs.translated: Now you're talking. I definitely will. In my soul, I believe Hero has been falsely accused. And I'll make sure that Claudio, the Prince, and anyone else who helped dishonor her know about it.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO enter.

paragraphs.original: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.
paragraphs.translated: The Prince and Claudio are hurrying this way.

paragraphs.original: Good e'en, good e'en.
paragraphs.translated: Good evening, good evening.

paragraphs.original: Good day to both of you.
paragraphs.translated: Good day to both of you.

paragraphs.original: Hear you, my lords -
paragraphs.translated: Listen, my lords -

paragraphs.original: We have some haste, Leonato.
paragraphs.translated: We're in a bit of a hurry, Leonato.

paragraphs.original:
Some haste, my lord! Well, fare you well, my lord.
Are you so hasty now? Well, all is one.
paragraphs.translated: A bit of a hurry, my lord! Well then, good bye, my lord. You're in a hurry, are you? Well then, don't bother.

paragraphs.original: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, don't quarrel with us, good old man.

paragraphs.original:
If he could right himself with quarreling,
Some of us would lie low.
paragraphs.translated: If it's fighting he is after, some of us here should run and hide.

paragraphs.original: Who wrongs him?
paragraphs.translated: Who has wronged him?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword.
I fear thee not.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, you have wronged me, you liar. Don't bother trying to intimidate me by putting your hand on your sword. I'm not scared of you.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, beshrew my hand
If it should give your age such cause of fear.
In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.
paragraphs.translated: Curse my hand if it ever threatened an old man like you. Really, I had no intention of going for my sword.

paragraphs.original:
Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag
What I have done being young, or what would do
Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,
Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me
That I am forced to lay my reverence by,
And with gray hairs and bruise of many days
Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors,
Oh, in a tomb where never scandal slept
Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.
paragraphs.translated: Damn you, don't mock and sneer at me. I'm not a doddering old fool who brags about the things he did when he was young, and what he would do now if he weren't so old. Claudio, I'm telling you right to your face that you have wronged me and my innocent child. I am forced to lay aside my old man's respectability, and with my gray hairs and my aching body I challenge you to a duel. You have ruined my innocent child. Your slander has broken her heart, and now she lies buried with her ancestors in a tomb - ancestors who had never been tainted by scandal until you caused one with your wickedness.

paragraphs.original: My villainy?
paragraphs.translated: My wickedness?

paragraphs.original: Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.
paragraphs.translated: Yours, Claudio, yours, I say.

paragraphs.original: You say not right, old man.
paragraphs.translated: You've got it wrong, old man.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, my lord,
I'll prove it on his body if he dare,
Despite his nice fence and his active practice,
His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, if he dares to accept my challenge, I'll beat him and prove he's guilty. I'll beat him despite his fancy fencing techniques and all the practicing he does, despite his youth and manliness.

paragraphs.original: Away! I will not have to do with you.
paragraphs.translated: Not a chance! I'll have nothing to do with you.

paragraphs.original:
Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast killed my child.
If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.
paragraphs.translated: You think you can get rid of me that easily? You killed my child. Take on someone your own size: if you kill me, boy, you'll have killed a man.

paragraphs.original:
He shall kill two of us, and men indeed,
But that's no matter. Let him kill one first.
Win me and wear me! Let him answer me. - 
Come, follow me, boy. Come, sir boy, come, follow me.
Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
paragraphs.translated: He'll have to kill both of us, and indeed we're both men. But let him start off easy by killing one of us. Come on - kill me and brag about it! Let me at him. Come on, come after me, little boy. Come on and get me. Little man, I'll be right in your face with my sword. I will, as surely as I am a gentleman.

paragraphs.original: Brother -
paragraphs.translated: Brother -

paragraphs.original:
Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece,
And she is dead, slandered to death by villains
That dare as well answer a man indeed
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue. - 
Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
paragraphs.translated: Quiet. God knows I loved my niece, and now she's dead - slandered to death by cowards who would just as likely fight a real man as I would grab a poisonous snake by the tongue. Boys, fools, braggers, scoundrels, babies!

paragraphs.original: Brother Anthony -
paragraphs.translated: Brother Anthony -

paragraphs.original:
Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple - 
Scrambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys,
That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,
Go anticly and show outward hideousness,
And speak off half a dozen dang'rous words
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst,
And this is all.
paragraphs.translated: Hold your peace. I know their kind, I know them exactly. They're petulant, disrespectful, fashion-crazy boys who lie and cheat and mock, defame and slander. They walk around in outlandish outfits, pretending to be brave and wild and saying a few inflammatory things about how they'll hurt their enemies - and that's all they do.

paragraphs.original: But brother Anthony -
paragraphs.translated: But brother Anthony -

paragraphs.original:
Come, 'tis no matter.
Do not you meddle. Let me deal in this.
paragraphs.translated: Don't, it's no big deal. Don't bother with it. Let me deal with this.

paragraphs.original:
Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
My heart is sorry for your daughter's death,
But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing
But what was true and very full of proof.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, we won't stay here and anger you further. I'm sorry about your daughter's death, but I swear our accusations were true, and backed up with proof.

paragraphs.original: My lord, my lord -
paragraphs.translated: My lord, my lord -

paragraphs.original: I will not hear you.
paragraphs.translated: I don't want to hear any more about it.

paragraphs.original: No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.
paragraphs.translated: No? Come on, brother! I'm determined to be heard by someone.

paragraphs.original: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.
paragraphs.translated: And you will be, or some people here will suffer for it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEONATO andANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK enters.

paragraphs.original: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here comes just the man we were looking for.

paragraphs.original: Now, Signior, what news?
paragraphs.translated: What's up, mister?

paragraphs.original:
Welcome, Signior. You are almost come to part almost a
fray.
paragraphs.translated:
Welcome, sir. You just missed a fight that was barely
avoided.

paragraphs.original:
We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two
old men without teeth.
paragraphs.translated:
We were about to have our noses snapped off by two
old men with no teeth.

paragraphs.original:
Leonato and his brother. What think'st thou? Had we
fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.
paragraphs.translated:
Leonato and his brother. What do you think? I think
if we had fought, we would have proven too young and
strong for them after all.

paragraphs.original:
In a false quarrel there is no true valor. I came to seek you
both.
paragraphs.translated:
There's no bravery in an unfair fight. I've been look-
ing for you two.

paragraphs.original:
We have been up and down to seek thee, for we are high-
proof melancholy and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt
thou use thy wit?
paragraphs.translated:
We've been looking for you, too. We're really
depressed. Will you tell us some jokes to beat our sad-
ness away?

paragraphs.original: It is in my scabbard. Shall I draw it?
paragraphs.translated:
My wit's in my
scabbard. Should I unsheath it?
scabbard

paragraphs.original: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?
paragraphs.translated: You wear your wit next to you?

paragraphs.original:
Never any did so, though very many have been beside their
wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels: draw to
pleasure us.
paragraphs.translated:
No one carries their wit next to them, though some
people are
beside their wit. Come on, draw your wit,
beside their wit



just as musicians draw their bows across the instru-
ments: draw for our pleasure.

paragraphs.original:
As I am an honest man, he looks pale. - Art thou sick, or
angry?
paragraphs.translated: Look: Benedick is so pale - are you sick, or angry?

paragraphs.original:
(to BENEDICK) What, courage, man! What though care
(to
)
killed a cat? Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
paragraphs.translated:
(to BENEDICK) Buck up, man!
Care may have killed the
(to
)
Care



cat, but you are strong enough to kill care. Lighten up.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an you charge it
against me. I pray you, choose another subject.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, don't even try to beat me in a battle of wits. I'll
meet all your attacks, even if you come charging at me
with a lance at full gallop. Choose another tack.

paragraphs.original:
(to DON PEDRO) Nay, then, give him another staff. This last
(to
)
was broke 'cross.
paragraphs.translated:
(to DON PEDRO) That was poor, Benedick! Give him
(to
)
another lance - that last one got broken in half.

paragraphs.original:
By this light, he changes more and more. I think he be angry
indeed.
paragraphs.translated:
Lord, he seems to be getting paler by the minute. I
think he really is angry.

paragraphs.original: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.
paragraphs.translated: If he is, that's his problem.

paragraphs.original: Shall I speak a word in your ear?
paragraphs.translated: Can I have a word with you privately?

paragraphs.original: God bless me from a challenge!
paragraphs.translated: God forbid he wants to challenge me!

paragraphs.original:
(aside to CLAUDIO) You are a villain. I jest not. I will make it
(aside to
)
good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you
dare. Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice. You
have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on
you. Let me hear from you.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only CLAUDIOcan hear) You are a vil-
(speaking so that only
can hear)
lain. I'm not kidding. I challenge you however you
like - with whatever weapons you choose, and whe-
never you want. Meet this challenge, or I'll say that
you're a coward. You've killed an innocent woman,
and you're going to pay dearly for her death. What do you say?

paragraphs.original: Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be there, and I'll enjoy myself.

paragraphs.original: What, a feast, a feast?
paragraphs.translated: What, are we having a feast?

paragraphs.original:
I' faith, I thank him. He hath bid me to a calf's head and a
capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my
knife's naught. Shall I not find a woodcock too?
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, we are. He has invited me to have a
calf's head and a capon. He says if I don't carve them up and serve them elegantly, he'll declare I have no skills with a knife. Should I go get us a woodcock, too?
calf's head and a capon

paragraphs.original: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, you have a very slow, rambling wit.

paragraphs.original:
I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit he other day. I
said thou hadst a fine wit. "True," said she, "a fine little
one." "No," said I, "a great wit." "Right," says she, "a great
gross one." "Nay," said I, "a good wit." "Just," said she, "it
hurts nobody." "Nay," said I, "the gentleman is wise."
"Certain," said she, "a wise gentleman." "Nay," said I, "he
hath the tongues." "That I believe," said she, "for he swore
a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on
Tuesday morning; there's a double tongue, there's two
tongues." Thus did she an hour together transshape thy
particular virtues. Yet at last she concluded with a sigh,
thou wast the proper'st man in Italy.
paragraphs.translated:
Benedick, Beatrice praised your wit the other day. I said you had a fine wit. "True," she said, "a fine little one." "No," I said, "a huge wit." "Right," she said, "a hugely awful one." "No," I said, "he has a good wit." "Exactly," she said, "it's good and mild; it doesn't hurt anyone." "No," I said, "Benedick is wise." "He is certainly," she said,
"a wise gentleman.""No," I said, "he can speak many languages:" "I can believe that," she said, "because he swore one thing to me on Monday night and took it back on Tuesday morning. He spoke two languages then." She turned all your virtues into vices just about an hour ago. But in the end she sighed and admitted you were the handsomest man in Italy.
"a wise gentleman."

paragraphs.original: For the which she wept heartily and said she cared not.
paragraphs.translated: She cried a lot at that, and said she didn't care.

paragraphs.original:
Yea, that she did. But yet for all that, an if she did not hate
him deadly, she would love him dearly. The old man's
daughter told us all.
paragraphs.translated: That she did. And yet for all that, if she didn't hate him to death, she'd love him to death. Leonato's daughter had told us everything.

paragraphs.original:
All, all. And, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in
the garden.
paragraphs.translated: Absolutely everything. And, moreover, God saw Benedick when he was hid in the garden.

paragraphs.original:
But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the sensible
Benedick's head?
paragraphs.translated: But when exactly will we see Benedick married?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, and text underneath: "Here dwells Benedick the
married man"?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, with the sign underneath him that says: "Here lives Benedick the married man"?

paragraphs.original:
Fare you well, boy. You know my mind. I will leave you now
to your gossip-like humor. You break jests as braggarts do
their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not. - My lord,
for your many courtesies I thank you. I must discontinue
your company.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, boy. You know what I intend. I'll leave you now to chatter and gossip like an old woman. The wit you flaunt is like a blunt sword - it can't hurt anyone, thank God. - My lord, I thank you for your many kindnesses. I'm leaving your court now.

paragraphs.original:
Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina. You have
among you killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord
Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be
with him.
paragraphs.translated: Your brother Don John the Bastard has run away from Messina. The three of you have killed a sweet, innocent woman. Lord Babyface over there will meet me in a duel, and good luck to him then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: He is in earnest.
paragraphs.translated: He's serious.

paragraphs.original:
In most profound earnest, and, I'll warrant you, for the love
of Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated: Very serious, and I'm sure it's because of Beatrice.

paragraphs.original: And hath challenged thee?
paragraphs.translated: And he challenged you to a duel?

paragraphs.original: Most sincerely.
paragraphs.translated: He did, very sincerely.

paragraphs.original:
What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and
hose and leaves off his wit!
paragraphs.translated: What a strange sight - a man who has put on all his fancy clothes but forgotten his brain at home!

paragraphs.original:
He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to
such a man.
paragraphs.translated: A guy like that is bigger than an ape, but the ape could be his doctor, it's so much smarter.

paragraphs.original:
But soft you, let me be. Pluck up, my heart, and be sad. Did
he not say my brother was fled?
paragraphs.translated: But wait a minute. Let me gather my wits and get serious here. Didn't he say my brother has run away?

paragraphs.original: Enter DOGBERRY,VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the WATCHMEN enter with CONRADE and BORACHIO.

paragraphs.original:
Come you, sir. If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er
weigh more reasons in her balance. Nay, an you be a cursing
hypocrite once, you must be looked to.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you. If they let you off, then we'll have to assume that Lady Justice has lost all her power. Since you are a lying hypocrite, we must look after you.

paragraphs.original: How now? Two of my brother's men bound! Borachio one!
paragraphs.translated: What's this? Two of my brother's men, all tied up! And Borachio is one of them!

paragraphs.original: Hearken after their offense, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Find out what they're being held for.

paragraphs.original: Officers, what offense have these men done?
paragraphs.translated: Officers, what crime have these men committed?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover,
they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders;
sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have
verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying
knaves.
paragraphs.translated: Well sir, they've lied; moreover, they have said things that were not true; secondarily, they are slanderers; sixth and lastly, they have falsely accused a lady; thirdly, they have confirmed things that did not in fact happen; and, in conclusion, they are lying scoundrels.

paragraphs.original:
First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee
what's their offense; sixth and lastly, why they are
committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge.
paragraphs.translated: First, I ask you what they've done; thirdly, I ask you what offense they're charged with; sixth and lastly, I ask you why they've been committed here; and, in conclusion, I ask what they're accused of.

paragraphs.original:
Rightly reasoned, and in his own division; and, by my
troth, there's one meaning well suited.
paragraphs.translated: Nicely done, and organized in just the way he'll understand. My God, he manages to say the same thing six different ways.

paragraphs.original:
(to BORACHIO and CONRADE) Who have you offended,
(to
and
)
masters, that you are thus bound to your answer? This
learned constable is too cunning to be understood. What's
your offense?
paragraphs.translated:
(to BORACHIO and CONRADE) What have you done, gentlemen? This educated constable is too brilliant for me to understand. What is your crime?
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
Sweet Prince, let me go no farther to mine answer. Do you
hear me, and let this count kill me. I have deceived even your
very eyes. What your wisdoms could not discover, these
shallow fools have brought to light, who in the night
overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your
brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero, how you
were brought into the orchard and saw me court Margaret in
Hero's garments, how you disgraced her when you should
marry her. My villainy they have upon record, which I had
rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. The
lady is dead upon mine and my master's false accusation.
And, briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a villain.
paragraphs.translated: Prince, I won't wait for my trial: listen to my story, and let the count kill me now. I tricked your own eyes. These stupid fools have uncovered what you in all your wisdom could not. They heard me confess to Conrade how Don John, your brother, prompted me to slander Hero - how you came to the orchard and saw me making sexual advances toward Margaret, who was disguised as Hero; how you disgraced Hero when you should have married her. They've recorded my crimes, and I would rather die than have to retell this shameful story. The lady has died because of the false accusations of me and my master. I desire nothing now but a criminal's punishment.
