paragraphs.original:
(to CLAUDIO) Runs not this speech like iron through your
(to
)
blood?
I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.
paragraphs.translated: His words are like poison to me.

paragraphs.original: Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and paid me well for doing it.

paragraphs.original:
He is composed and framed of treachery,
And fled he is upon this villainy.
paragraphs.translated: He is made of treachery, and has run away to avoid his crimes.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.
paragraphs.translated: Sweet Hero; when I imagine you now, you seem as beautiful as you did when I first loved you.

paragraphs.original:
Come, bring away the plaintiffs. By this time our sexton
hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. And,
masters, do not forget to specify, when time and place shall
serve, that I am an ass.
paragraphs.translated:
Come, take away the
plaintiffs. By now the sexton will have reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. (to CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) And, gentlemen, please do not forget to specify, whenever it is convenient, that I am an ass.
plaintiffs



(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton
too.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes Master Signior Leonato with the sexton.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO andANTONIO, with the SEXTON
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO enter with the SEXTON.

paragraphs.original:
Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes,
That, when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him. Which of these is he?
paragraphs.translated: Which one of them did it? Let me see what he looks like, so when I see another man who resembles him, I'll know to avoid him. Which one is it?

paragraphs.original: If you would know your wronger, look on me.
paragraphs.translated: If you want to see your deceiver, then look at me.

paragraphs.original:
Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed
Mine innocent child?
paragraphs.translated: Are you the slave who, with your slanderous words, killed my innocent child?

paragraphs.original: Yea, even I alone.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I am the one.

paragraphs.original:
No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
Here stand a pair of honorable men - 
A third is fled - that had a hand in it. - 
I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death.
Record it with your high and worthy deeds.
'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.
paragraphs.translated:
No, villain, but you didn't work alone. (indicating CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) For here are two noblemen  - the third has run away - who helped you. (to CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) Thank you, gentlemen, for my daughter's death. Make a note of it on your long lists of righteous and worthy deeds. It was very brave of you.
(indicating
and
)
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself.
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin. Yet sinned I not
But in mistaking.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know how to ask you for forgiveness, but I have to say something. Choose your revenge. Punish me through any means you can devise, though I sinned by mistake.

paragraphs.original:
By my soul, nor I,
And yet to satisfy this good old man
I would bend under any heavy weight
That he'll enjoin me to.
paragraphs.translated: Me too - but to satisfy this good old man, I too will bear any punishment he gives me.

paragraphs.original:
I cannot bid you bid my daughter live - 
That were impossible - but, I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here
How innocent she died. And if your love
Can labor ought in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb
And sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight.
Tomorrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that's dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us.
Give her the right you should have given her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.
paragraphs.translated: I can't ask you to make my daughter live - that's impossible - but I beg you both to tell the people of Messina that she was innocent when she died. And if your love can produce something from its sadness, write a poem for her; hang it on her grave and sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight. Then come to my house tomorrow morning, and since you couldn't be my son-in-law, be my nephew instead. My brother has a daughter who looks exactly like Hero; this girl is heir to both our estates. Marry her as you should have married her cousin, and I will let my revenge die.

paragraphs.original:
O noble sir!
Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
I do embrace your offer; and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, noble sir! Your overwhelming kindness makes me weep. I willingly accept your offer and put my future in your hands.

paragraphs.original:
Tomorrow then I will expect your coming.
Tonight I take my leave. This naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.
paragraphs.translated: I will see you tomorrow, then. Now I have to leave. This wicked man will be brought face to face with Margaret, who I believe was hired by Don John to take part in this plot.

paragraphs.original:
No, by my soul, she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous
In any thing that I do know by her.
paragraphs.translated: No, she wasn't, and she didn't know anything about it. She has always been honest and good.

paragraphs.original:
(to LEONATO) Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under
(to
)
white and black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me
ass. I beseech you, let it be remembered in his punishment.
And also the watch heard them talk of one Deformed. They
say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it and
borrows money in God's name, the which he hath used so
long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted and
will lend nothing for God's sake. Pray you, examine him
upon that point.
paragraphs.translated:
(to LEONATO) Also, sir, this hasn't been put down in writing, but I should let you know that this
plaintiff here, the criminal, did in fact call me an ass. Please remember that when you're punishing him. Plus, the watchmen heard the criminals talking about some man named
Deformed. They say that he has an earring made out of a key, with a lock hanging from it. Apparently, he borrows money from people in the name of God and then never pays it back, which angers everyone so much that they now refuse to fund anything in the name of God. Make sure you ask him about this.
(to
)
plaintiff



Deformed

paragraphs.original: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you for all your efforts.

paragraphs.original:
Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent
youth, and I praise God for you.
paragraphs.translated: You speak like a very thankful and respectful boy, and may God bless you.

paragraphs.original:
(giving him money) There's for thy pains.
(giving him money)
paragraphs.translated:
(giving DOGBERRY money) This is for your trouble.
(giving
money)

paragraphs.original: God save the foundation!
paragraphs.translated: God save the charitable organization!

paragraphs.original: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.
paragraphs.translated: Go, you're relieved of your duty. Thank you.

paragraphs.original:
I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech
your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.
God keep your Worship! I wish your Worship well. God
restore you to health! I humbly give you leave to depart, and
if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! - 
Come, neighbor.
paragraphs.translated:
I leave a slimy bastard with you, your Worship, for you to punish and make an example of. God bless your Worship! I wish you well. I hope that God restores you to health. I will humbly let you go now, God
prohibiting we will meet again in the future. - Come on, man.
prohibiting

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DOGBERRY andVERGES
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY and VERGES exit.

paragraphs.original: Until tomorrow morning, lords, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: I'll see you tomorrow morning, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, my lords. We look for you tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, gentlemen. We'll see you tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: We will not fail.
paragraphs.translated: We'll be there.

paragraphs.original: Tonight I'll mourn with Hero.
paragraphs.translated: I will mourn Hero tonight.

paragraphs.original:
(to the Watch)
(to the Watch)
Bring you these fellows on. - We'll talk with Margaret,
How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.
paragraphs.translated:
(to the watchmen) Bring these criminals with us. We'll go talk to Margaret, to see how she got involved with this worthless man.
(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK andMARGARET
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK andMARGARET enter.

paragraphs.original:
Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my
hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated: Please Margaret, help me write this poem for Beatrice.

paragraphs.original: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?
paragraphs.translated: Afterward, will you write a sonnet for me, praising my beauty?

paragraphs.original:
In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come
over it, for in most comely truth thou deservest it.
paragraphs.translated: I'll write you such a glorious sonnet, Margaret, that no man will ever be able to come over it. You certainly deserve it.

paragraphs.original:
To have no man come over me! Why, shall I always keep
below stairs?
paragraphs.translated:
No man will come
over me! What a life that would be!
over me

paragraphs.original: Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth; it catches.
paragraphs.translated: Your wit is as quick as a greyhound's jaws - it catches whatever it goes after.

paragraphs.original:
And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit but hurt
not.
paragraphs.translated: And your wit is as blunt as a practice sword, with its dull tip; it hits people but doesn't hurt them.

paragraphs.original:
A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman. And
so, I pray thee, call Beatrice. I give thee the bucklers.
paragraphs.translated:
It's just that my wit is very gentlemanly, Margaret, and refuses to hurt a woman. Now please, tell Beatrice to come out. I admit defeat; I give you the
bucklers.
bucklers

paragraphs.original: Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own.
paragraphs.translated:
No, you should give a woman your sword - we have our own
bucklers!
bucklers

paragraphs.original:
If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with
a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for maids.
paragraphs.translated: Watch out, though, Margaret - virgins shouldn't be brandishing their bucklers around.

paragraphs.original: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go get Beatrice for you, who can walk here by herself - she has legs.

paragraphs.original: And therefore will come.
paragraphs.translated: So that means she'll come.

paragraphs.original: Exit MARGARET
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET exits.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
The god of love,
The god of love
That sits above,
That sits above
And knows me, and knows me,
And knows me, and knows me
How pitiful I deserve - 
How pitiful I deserve
I mean in singing. But in loving, Leander the good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole bookful of these quondam carpetmongers, whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a blank verse, why, they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in rhyme. I have tried. I can find out no rhyme to "lady" but "baby" - an innocent rhyme; for "scorn," "horn" - a hard rhyme; for, "school," "fool" - a babbling rhyme; very ominous endings. No, I was not born under a rhyming planet, nor I cannot woo in festival terms.
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
The god of love
The god of love
He sits in heaven above
He sits in heaven above
And he knows me, he knows me
And he knows me, he knows me
He knows how much pity I deserve - 
He knows how much pity I deserve - 
I'm really a pitiful singer. But as a lover, well, that's another story. Take
Leander, Troilus, or an entire book's worth of those legendary lover–boys, whose names sound so smooth and nice in a line of verse - not one of them has been driven as crazy by love as I have been. But I can't prove it in a poem. I have tried. I can't think of any rhyme for "lady" but "baby," which is a childish rhyme. The only rhyme for "scorn" I can come up with is
"horn" - a bit off for a love poem. Nothing rhymes with "school" but "fool," and that's a ridiculous jingle. These are all very unpromising line endings. No, I wasn't destined to be a poet, and I can't woo a lady with pretty words.
Leander, Troilus



"horn"

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters.

paragraphs.original: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?
paragraphs.translated: Beatrice, have you come because I called for you?

paragraphs.original: Yea, Signior, and depart when you bid me.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir, and I'll leave when you ask me to.

paragraphs.original: Oh , stay but till then!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, well, stay till then!

paragraphs.original:
"Then" is spoken. Fare you well now. And yet, ere I go, let
me go with that I came, which is, with knowing what hath
passed between you and Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: There - you said "then." So I'll leave now. But before I go, let me get what I came for. What happened between you and Claudio?

paragraphs.original: Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.
paragraphs.translated: I spoke angry, foul words to him, and with that I will kiss you.

paragraphs.original:
Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul
breath, and foul breath is noisome. Therefore I will depart
unkissed.
paragraphs.translated: If you had foul words in your mouth, then your breath must be foul, and foul breath is nauseating. Thus, I'll leave without being kissed.

paragraphs.original:
Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so
forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio
undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear
from him, or I will subscribe him a coward. And I pray thee
now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall
in love with me?
paragraphs.translated: Your wit is so forceful, it frightens the very meaning out of your words. But I will tell you this very plainly: I have challenged Claudio, and either he'll accept the challenge or admit he's a coward. Now, tell me - which of my bad qualities did you fall in love with first?

paragraphs.original:
For them all together, which maintained so politic a state of
evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle
with them. But for which of my good parts did you first
suffer love for me?
paragraphs.translated: With all of them at once: they work together to create such an entirely evil person that no good ever manages to enter the mix. But tell me - which of my good qualities first made you suffer love for me?

paragraphs.original:
Suffer love! A good epithet! I do suffer love indeed, for I
love thee against my will.
paragraphs.translated: Suffer love! That's a good way of putting it. I do suffer love, because I love you against my will.

paragraphs.original:
In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor heart, if you spite
it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for I will never love
that which my riend hates.
paragraphs.translated: You love me in spite of your heart, I think. If you spite your heart for my sake, then I will spite it for yours. I will never love the thing my friend hates.

paragraphs.original: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.
paragraphs.translated: You and I are too wise to woo each other peacefully.

paragraphs.original:
It appears not in this confession. There's not one wise man
among twenty that will praise himself.
paragraphs.translated: It's said that no truly wise man will praise himself. If you say that you are wise, it's likely you're not.

paragraphs.original:
An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in the lime of
good neighbors. If a man do not erect in this age his own
tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than
the bell rings and the widow weeps.
paragraphs.translated: That's an old proverb, Beatrice, from the time when neighbors praised each other. In this day and age, if a man doesn't erect his own monument before he dies, he won't be remembered past the funeral bell's ringing and his widow's crying.

paragraphs.original: And how long is that, think you?
paragraphs.translated: Exactly how long is that, do you think?

paragraphs.original:
Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum.
Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm,
his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary, to be
the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much
for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is
praiseworthy. An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
paragraphs.translated: About an hour for the ringing and fifteen minutes for the crying. That's why it's better for wise men to trumpet their own virtues, like I do. That's why I praise myself, who - if I do say so myself - is quite praiseworthy. But tell me, how is your cousin?

paragraphs.original: Very ill.
paragraphs.translated: She's very sick.

paragraphs.original: And how do you?
paragraphs.translated: And how are you?

paragraphs.original: Very ill, too.
paragraphs.translated: I'm very sick, too.

paragraphs.original:
Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I leave you too,
for here comes one in haste.
paragraphs.translated: Have faith, love me, and you will get better. And that's where I'll end, because someone is hurrying this way.

paragraphs.original: Enter URSULA
paragraphs.translated: URSULA enters.

paragraphs.original:
Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder's old coil at
home. It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely
accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused, and Don
John is the author of all, who is fled and gone. Will you
come presently?
paragraphs.translated: Madam, you have to go to your uncle's. There's a huge racket going on there. It's been proven that Lady Hero is innocent, that the Prince and Claudio have been utterly deceived, and that Don John - who has run away - is the source of all the trouble. Will you come immediately?

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: Will you go hear this news, Signior?
paragraphs.translated: Will you come with me to hear this news, sir?

paragraphs.original:
I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy
eyes - and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle's.
paragraphs.translated: I will live in your heart, die in your lap, and be buried in your eyes - and, what's more, I will go with you to your uncle's.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, three or four LORDS with tapers, and musicians
DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDROand CLAUDIO enter with three or four LORDS carrying candles, and musicians.

paragraphs.original: Is this the monument of Leonato?
paragraphs.translated: Is this the family tomb of Leonato?

paragraphs.original: It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: It is, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
(reading an epitaph)
(reading an epitaph)
Done to death by slanderous tongues
Was the Hero that here lies.
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies.
So the life that died with shame
Lives in death with glorious fame.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading an epitaph)
(reading an epitaph)
Here lies Hero,
The heroic maiden killed by slanderous words.
To repay her for her troubles, Death
Gives her undying fame.
So the life that died with shame
Lives on with fame.

paragraphs.original: Hangs the scroll
paragraphs.translated: (he hangs the scroll)

paragraphs.original:
Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dumb.
Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
(Song)
(Song)
Pardon, goddess of the night,
Pardon, goddess of the night
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
Those that slew thy virgin knight
For the which with songs of woe
For the which with songs of woe
Round about her tomb they go.
Round about her tomb they go
Midnight, assist our moan.
Midnight, assist our moan
Help us to sigh and groan
Help us to sigh and groan
Heavily, heavily.
Heavily, heavily
Graves, yawn and yield your dead,
Graves, yawn and yield your dead
Till death be utterèd,
Till death be utterèd
Heavily, heavily.
Heavily, heavily
paragraphs.translated:
This epitaph will hang here forever,
Continuing to praise Hero after I die.
Now start the music, and sing the solemn hymn.
(singing)
(singing)
Please pardon, goddess of the night,
Please pardon, goddess of the night
The men who killed your
virgin knight.
The men who killed your
virgin knight



These men now walk around her tomb,
These men now walk around her tomb
Singing songs of woe.
Singing songs of woe
Oh, midnight, join our moaning
Oh, midnight, join our moaning
Help us with our sighs and groaning
Help us with our sighs and groaning
Heavily, heavily.
Heavily, heavily
Graves, open up and release your corpses
Graves, open up and release your corpses
Until Hero's death is fully mourned
Until Hero's death is fully mourned




Heavily, heavily.
Heavily, heavily

paragraphs.original:
Now, unto thy bones good night!
Yearly will I do this rite.
paragraphs.translated: Now I say good night to your bones, Hero. I will perform this ceremony every year.

paragraphs.original:
Good morrow, masters. Put your torches out.
The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day,
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
Thanks to you all, and leave us. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, gentlemen. Put out your torches. The wolves have finished preying for the night, and look - the gentle dawn is rising, dappling the sleepy eastern sky with spots of light.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, masters. Each his several way.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, gentlemen. We go our separate ways.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LORDS and Musicians
paragraphs.translated: LORDS and musicians exit

paragraphs.original:
Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds,
And then to Leonato's we will go.
paragraphs.translated: Come, let's go and change our clothes. Then we'll visit Leonato's.

paragraphs.original:
And Hymen now with luckier issue speed 's
Than this for whom we rendered up this woe.
paragraphs.translated:
And I hope
Hymen will give us better luck than Hero got.
Hymen

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO,ANTONIO, BENEDICK,BEATRICE, MARGARET,URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, andHERO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO, ANTONIO,BENEDICK, BEATRICE,MARGARET, URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, and HERO enter.

paragraphs.original: Did I not tell you she was innocent?
paragraphs.translated: Didn't I tell you she was innocent?

paragraphs.original:
So are the Prince and Claudio, who accused her
Upon the error that you heard debated.
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will, as it appears
In the true course of all the question.
paragraphs.translated: And the Prince and Claudio, who accused her, are innocent as well, because they were deceived by Don John. Margaret is partially guilty, although our investigation shows that she acted unintentionally.

paragraphs.original: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'm glad that everything has been sorted out.

paragraphs.original:
And so am I, being else by faith enforced
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.
paragraphs.translated: Me too - otherwise I would have had to duel with Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you, come hither masked.
The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour
To visit me. - You know your office, brother.
You must be father to your brother's daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: Hero, you and the other women should all retreat to a room. When I send for you, come out wearing masks. The Prince and Claudio are supposed to be here by now. - You know your job, brother. You have to pretend to be your niece's father, and give her away to Claudio.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt Ladies
paragraphs.translated: The ladies exit.

paragraphs.original: Which I will do with confirmed countenance.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do that, without giving away our secret.

paragraphs.original: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.
paragraphs.translated: Friar, I think I need a favor from you.

paragraphs.original: To do what, Signior?
paragraphs.translated: What do you need me to do?

paragraphs.original:
To bind me or undo me, one of them. - 
Signior Leonato, truth it is, good Signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favor.
paragraphs.translated: To tie me up, or to undo me: one or the other. Signior Leonato, the truth is, your niece likes me.

paragraphs.original: That eye my daughter lent her; 'tis most true.
paragraphs.translated: She sees you with the eyes my daughter lent her, it's true.

paragraphs.original: And I do with an eye of love requite her.
paragraphs.translated: And I see her also through the eyes of love.

paragraphs.original:
The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio and the Prince. But what's your will?
paragraphs.translated: And those eyes were endowed with sight by Claudio, the Prince, and me. But what did you want?

paragraphs.original:
Your answer, sir, is enigmatical.
But for my will, my will is your goodwill
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoined
In the state of honorable marriage - 
In which, good Friar, I shall desire your help.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I'm puzzled by what you just said. But as far as what I want - I want you to give Beatrice and me your blessing to be married. That, good Friar, is where you come in.

paragraphs.original: My heart is with your liking.
paragraphs.translated: Our wishes are aligned, then: I give you my blessing.

paragraphs.original:
And my help.
Here comes the Prince and Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: And I'll help you. Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO, and two or three others
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO enter with two or three others.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow to this fair assembly.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning to all these lovely people.

paragraphs.original:
Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio.
We here attend you. Are you yet determined
Today to marry with my brother's daughter?
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, Prince; good morning, Claudio. We're waiting here for you. Are you still set on marrying my brother's daughter?

paragraphs.original: I'll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.
paragraphs.translated:
I wouldn't change my mind even if she were
black-skinned.
black-skinned

paragraphs.original: Call her forth, brother. Here's the friar ready.
paragraphs.translated: Bring her out, brother. The friar's ready.

paragraphs.original: Exit ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, Benedick. What's the matter? Your face looks like the month of February - full of frost, storms, and cloudiness.

paragraphs.original:
I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
Tush, fear not, man. We'll tip thy horns with gold,
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee
As once Europa did at lusty Jove
When he would play the noble beast in love.
paragraphs.translated:
I think he's nervous - he's about to become the savage bull who got domesticated. Oh, don't worry about it - we'll dip your
horns in gold and make you pretty, and you'll delight all of Europe, just like Jove delighted Europa when he was a bull.
horns



he

paragraphs.original:
Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low,
And some such strange bull leapt your father's cow
And got a calf in that same noble feat
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.
paragraphs.translated:
Jove came to earth lowing for love. A strange bull just like him mated with one of your father's cows and, voilà, gave birth to a calf like you - you bleat the same as him.
Jove

paragraphs.original: For this I owe you. Here comes other reck'nings.
paragraphs.translated: I'll get you for that one. But here are other matters to be dealt with.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO,HERO, BEATRICE,MARGARET, URSULA, the ladies masked
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO, HERO,BEATRICE, MARGARET,URSULA enter. The ladies wear masks.

paragraphs.original: Which is the lady I must seize upon?
paragraphs.translated: Which is the lady I'm supposed to marry?

paragraphs.original: This same is she, and I do give you her.
paragraphs.translated: This one, and I will give her to you.

paragraphs.original: Why, then she's mine. - Sweet, let me see your face.
paragraphs.translated: Well, then she's the one for me. Sweetheart, let me see your face.

paragraphs.original:
No, that you shall not till you take her hand
Before this friar and swear to marry her.
paragraphs.translated: No, you can't do that until you take her hand and, in front of this friar, swear to marry her.

paragraphs.original:
(to HERO) Give me your hand before this holy friar.
(to
)
I am your husband, if you like of me.

And when I lived, I was your other wife,
And when you loved, you were my other husband.
(She unmasks)
(She unmasks)
paragraphs.translated:
And when I lived, I was your other wife. And when you loved me, you were my other husband.(she removes her mask)
(she removes her mask)

paragraphs.original: Another Hero!
paragraphs.translated: It's another Hero!

paragraphs.original:
Nothing certainer.
One Hero died defiled, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.
paragraphs.translated: Exactly right. One Hero died when she was slandered, but I am alive. And as surely as I am alive, I am a virgin.

paragraphs.original: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!
paragraphs.translated: It's the former Hero! The Hero that died!

paragraphs.original: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.
paragraphs.translated: She was only dead, my lord, as long as her slander lived.

paragraphs.original:
All this amazement can I qualify
When after that the holy rites are ended
I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death.
Meantime let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.
paragraphs.translated: I can confirm that all these shocking things are true. After the wedding ceremony, I'll tell you all about beautiful Hero's "death." In the meantime, just accept all these wonderful things, and let's head to the chapel.

paragraphs.original: Soft and fair, Friar. - Which is Beatrice?
paragraphs.translated: Wait a moment, Friar. Which one of you is Beatrice?

paragraphs.original:
(unmasking) I answer to that name. What is your will?
(unmasking)
paragraphs.translated:
(taking off her mask) That's my name. What do you want?
(taking off her mask)

paragraphs.original: Do not you love me?
paragraphs.translated: Do you love me?

paragraphs.original: Why no, no more than reason.
paragraphs.translated: No, no more than is reasonable.

paragraphs.original:
Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio
Have been deceived. They swore you did.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived. They swore you did.

paragraphs.original: Do not you love me?
paragraphs.translated: Do you love me?

paragraphs.original: Troth, no, no more than reason.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, no - no more than is reasonable.

paragraphs.original:
Why then, my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula
Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, Margaret, Ursula, and my cousin have been very much deceived, for they swore you did.

paragraphs.original: They swore that you were almost sick for me.
paragraphs.translated: They swore that you were sick with love for me.

paragraphs.original: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.
paragraphs.translated: They swore that you were nearly dead with love for me.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, well. So you don't love me?

paragraphs.original: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.
paragraphs.translated: No, I don't - except as a friend.

paragraphs.original: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, niece, I'm sure you love him.

paragraphs.original:
And I'll be sworn upon 't that he loves her,
For here's a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashioned to Beatrice.
(Shows a paper)
(Shows a paper)
paragraphs.translated:
And I'll swear that he loves her. Here's a clumsy sonnet, in Benedick's handwriting, dedicated to Beatrice. (holding up a piece of paper)
(holding up a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original:
And here's another,
Writ in my cousin's hand, stol'n from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedick.
(Shows a paper)
(Shows a paper)
paragraphs.translated:
And here's another poem, which I stole from my cousin's pocket - in her handwriting and all about her adoration for Benedick. (holding up a piece of paper)
(holding up a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original:
A miracle! Here's our own hands against our hearts. Come,
I will have thee, but, by this light, I take thee for pity.
paragraphs.translated: What a miracle! Our handwriting gives away our hearts. Come on, I'll take you, but honestly I'm only doing it out of pity.

paragraphs.original:
I would not deny you, but, by this good day, I yield upon
great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told
you were in a consumption.
paragraphs.translated: I won't say no to you, but let it be known that I'm only doing this after a lot of persuasion and to save your life  - I hear you were quickly wasting away without me.

paragraphs.original: Peace! I will stop your mouth.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, shut up! I'll stop your mouth with a kiss.

paragraphs.original: They kiss
paragraphs.translated: They kiss.

paragraphs.original: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?
paragraphs.translated: How does it feel to be Benedick the Married Man?

paragraphs.original:
I'll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackers cannot
flout me out of my humor. Dost thou think I care for a satire
or an epigram? No. If a man will be beaten with brains, he
shall wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do
purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that
the world can say against it, and therefore never flout at me
for what I have said against it. For man is a giddy thing, and
this is my conclusion. - For thy part, Claudio, I did think to
have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman,
live unbruised, and love my cousin.
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell you what, Prince: a whole university full of wisecrackers couldn't change my mood today. You think I care what I'm called? Well, I don't. If a man is always afraid of what others think, he won't even dare to dress nicely, because he'll be afraid people will talk about him. In short, since I intend to get married, I won't hear anyone say a bad thing about it. So don't go making fun of me for what I said before. Man is a giddy, flighty thing: that's my conclusion. And Claudio - though I'm sure I would have beaten you in our duel - since you're likely to become my relative, I'll let you go, unbruised, and love my cousin Hero.

paragraphs.original:
I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I
might have cudgeled thee out of thy single life, to make thee
a double-dealer, which out of question, thou wilt be, if my
cousin do not look exceedingly narrowly to thee.
paragraphs.translated:
I was sort of hoping you would say no to Beatrice, so that I could have smacked you out of your single life and made you a
double dealer. Which you'll probably turn into anyway, if my cousin Beatrice doesn't keep you on a short leash.
double dealer

paragraphs.original:
Come, come, we are friends. Let's have a dance ere we are
married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives'
heels.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, we're all friends. Let's do a dance, and have some fun, before we're wed.

paragraphs.original: We'll have dancing afterward.
paragraphs.translated: We'll dance after the wedding.

paragraphs.original:
First, of my word! Therefore play, music. - Prince, thou art
sad. Get thee a wife, get thee a wife. There is no staff more
reverend than one tipped with horn.
paragraphs.translated:
No, before! Musicians, play us a song. - Prince, you look sad. You should get a wife! Your royal staff would be so much more impressive if it were topped off by a
horn.
horn

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original:
(to DON PEDRO) My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight
(to
)
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

(to DON PEDRO) Think not on him till tomorrow. I'll devise
(to
)
thee brave punishments for him. - Strike up, pipers.
Dance
paragraphs.translated: They all dance.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.
